January 28th, 1937.

Sir:

When visiting the Kuper Island Indian Residential School this week, my attention was drawn to the state of the lighting system for the school.

The Reverend Principal has been negotiating with the Lister Agents who installed this plant in the first place, and I am now enclosing a letter from their Agent, as well as one from the Reverend Principal which speak for themselves.

Like all modern machinery improvements are being made with the result that the present plant has gone out of date, and it is going to cost so much more to put it in shape, as the parts would have to be especially made at the factory, then one would only have an old machine.

The gas running plant is today practically out of use compared with the oil running diesel which can be run for at least one third of the cost.

It is quite certain that something has to be done this Summer, in the way of putting the plant in order, and I would like to recommend that this plant be changed to new diesel engines, and it will be necessary to have arrangements have so that the plant can be changed during the Summer holidays which are in July.

At the present moment the plant is in such shape that every care has to be taken to see that the lights are turned at every opportunity to save the engines, and often causing much inconvenience.

Your obedient servant,

H. Graham
Indian Agent

Ottawa, February 3, 1937.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo, with reference to the lighting system at the Kuper Island Indian Residential School.

The contents of your letter are being communicated to Mr. MacKay, Indian Commissioner. He is being requested to further investigate the matter and report to the Department.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

H. Graham, Esq.
Indian Agent,
Duncan, B.C.
Ottawa, February 3, 1937.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed are letters recently forwarded to the Department by Mr. H. Graham, Indian Agent, Duncan, B.C. You will note that these refer to the lighting plant at the Kuper Island Indian Residential School. The present lighting plant was installed in the year 1926-27. The cost of the Lister plant, wiring and installation was approximately $10,000. In addition, new batteries were supplied at a cost of $575.00 in the year 1930.

Our Estimates for the coming fiscal year have already been submitted to Parliament, and no provision was made for a new lighting system at the Kuper Island School. Our Appropriation is so limited that it is practically impossible to provide funds for an expenditure as heavy as the estimate given by Messrs. Hoffars Limited.

The Department would appreciate your visiting the Kuper Island School at your convenience, and inspecting the lighting plant and reporting as to the minimum expenditure required to place this plant in working condition.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

D. M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Victoria, B.C.

Gentlemen:

I have to refer to Requisition No. 997 of October 8th, last, to supply two (2) No. 127 - 3 Singer sewing machines to be delivered to Rev. Jos. Guerts, S.M.M., Kuper Island Indian Residential School, Kuper Island, via Vancouver Barge Transportation, Vancouver, B.C. These machines were to be supplied at the price of $63.75 each, less 45% gross cash.

The enclosed statement has been received, but does not show the discount allowed. The account covering the cost of these machines should have been forwarded to Rev. Jos. Guerts, Kuper Island, B.C., and the discount allowed should be shown on the account.

If the account covering the cost of these machines has not been forwarded to Rev. Father Guerts, I would request that this be done at the earliest possible date. It is necessary that he certify the account before payment can be made. We are anxious to receive the account in order that payment can be made before our books close at the end of the present fiscal year - on the 31st ultimo.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

Re 152-0-5 of Feb. 3rd, 1937, Kuper Island Residential School Power Plant

During my recent visit to Ottawa, the question of the repair or replacement of the power plant of the Kuper Island Residential School was discussed with Mr. Hoey and Mr. Phelan and, as a result, I was requested to ascertain if replacement could possibly be made for a lower estimate than that submitted by Hoffars Ltd., Vancouver, and also, to include in my reply, information regarding the approximate cost of repairing the present plant.

While in Vancouver recently I interviewed Mr. Vivian of the Vivian Engine Works and, suggested that he visit Kuper Island, look over our plant and submit an estimate of the cost of installing the power machinery and equipment necessary to meet the requirements of the school. On May 13th Mr. Vivian examined our plant at Kuper Island and discussed the question of replacement with the Rev. Principal and has outlined in the attached letter what he would recommend for the school and the cost of the new unit installed.

The Vivian engine is made in the city of Vancouver and is a product of high quality. Those who have this make of engine speak very well of its service. It has an advantage over the outside product in that parts can be obtained readily and also that the manufacturer is in a position to personally look into any troubles that may develop in the machinery installed by his firm.

The cost of the necessary repair to recondition the present units is placed at approximately $1100. It is considered this would be an unwarranted expense as these units, being of the gasoline type, are now obsolete.

After looking into this matter very carefully, and as a result of interviews with persons in a position to give reliable information and advice, I strongly recommend the purchase of a Vivian 2 cylinder 20 H.P. 600 r.p.m., Stationary Diesel Engine with direct connection to a 12 K.W. Generator, to replace the present plant at the Kuper Island Residential School.

The price quoted by Mr. Vivian is approximately $1200 less than that submitted by Hoffars Ltd., when the value of the 6 H.P. gas engine, which Hoffars Ltd. want as part of the trade in equipment, and the cost of the concrete foundation and the necessary labour which is to be borne by the school are considered.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
MEMORANDUM:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Last January, Mr. H. Graham, Indian Agent, Duncan, B.C., advised the Department that the lighting system at the Kuper Island Indian Residential School was worn out and required either extensive repair or replacement.

Indian Commissioner MacKay was instructed to visit the school and carefully examine the lighting system. He reports that the replacement of the present system is absolutely necessary, and suggests the installation of the following:

One 2 cylinder 20 H.P., 600 r.p.m. Stationary VIVIAN Diesel engine, direct connected to a 12 KW Generator, delivered and completely installed at Kuper Island, including necessary electrical work, taking in trade the present 2 cylinder gasoline set with generator, for the net price of ........... $2,450.00.

Commissioner MacKay has received from the Vivian Engine Works Limited, 1090 West Sixth Avenue, Vancouver, B.C., a quotation of $2,450.00, plus sales tax, for the installation, and strongly recommends the purchase of the Vivian 2 cylinder 20 H.P. Diesel engine.

- Funds
Funds for this purpose are available in the Appropriation for Indian Education.

The Kuper Island Residential School is in the Cowichan Agency, Vancouver Island, Electoral District of Namaste, B.C.

I would appreciate receiving your approval to place the order with the Vivian Engine Works Limited, Vancouver.

T.R.M
Acting Director.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your 152-0/5 of the 30th ultimo regarding the replacement of the power plant at Kuper Island School, I am forwarding herewith Mr. Vivian's letter covering the information asked for.

It will be observed that Mr. Vivian is submitting an alternative proposal, the details of which are embodied in a separate letter enclosed, because of the length of time required to obtain a 600 r.p.m. generator. The costs in the alternative plan are the same, i.e., $2450.00 plus sales tax, nor is there any change in the equipment with the exception of the generator, which is of larger capacity and, as Mr. Vivian states, more costly to his company.

As the school re-opens on September 1st it would be well to have the new engine and equipment installed by that date if possible.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,

Mr. Jackson,

Re: Purchase of Diesel-Generator Set for Kuper Island Indian Residential School.

On June 17th last the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch advised the Deputy Minister the lighting plant at the above school was worn out and required either extensive repairs or replacement; that Indian Commissioner McKay had been instructed to examine and report on the situation; that the Commissioner had recommended the purchase of a new engine and generator to be supplied and installed by the Vivian Engine Works of Vancouver, at a cost of $2,450.00 plus sales tax.

On June 21st the Director wrote further, strongly recommending that this equipment be purchased from the Vivian Company as their engine was made in Vancouver, hence any service and repair parts needed could be quickly obtained. He also stated that a price obtained from Hoffars Limited was $1200 higher than that of the Vivian Company.

An Officer of the Purchasing Division consulted with Mr. Hickey, Electrical Engineer, Public Works Department, on the suitability of the equipment offered by the Vivian Company and on the price quoted by them. Mr. Hickey required further details and specifications before giving any definite opinion. These details and specifications have been received and are, briefly, as follow:

Engine One Vivian two cylinder 35 H. P. Diesel Engine, with electric starter and standard built-in equipment $2,000.00 Plus 8% sales tax. 160.00

Mr. Hickey states that the engine offered is of ample power; that the generator is satisfactory for the work and of reputable make; and that in view of the fact that it is desirable that the equipment be installed before school opens on September 1st it is his recommendation that the tender of the Vivian Company be accepted.

The Director of the Indian Affairs Branch has written, July 19th, pointing out that school opens on September 1st "and it is necessary that the new engine and equipment should be installed by that date."

I have, therefore, to recommend that an order be placed with the Vivian Engine Works of Vancouver for the above equipment and work, without calling for competitive bids, other than the one of Hoffars Limited, mentioned by the Director of the Indian Affairs Branch, and would quote Section 36, Chapter 166 re Statutes, which provides that "A work of pressing emergency, in which delay would be dangerous to the public interest" may be proceeded with, without calling for tenders.

THE VIVIAN DIESEL, a product of years of practical experience, was designed with careful consideration given to many desirable features, among which are:

Dependability: This is one of the chief requisites of any prime mover. Our policy of using only the highest grade materials; the special alloys which we have developed, and the well-supported, balanced base castings, of sufficient thickness without producing ponderous weight, have played their important part in contributing toward that dependability which is so characteristic of the VIVIAN Diesel.

Economy: The well known economy of the Diesel engine is due to the high compression ratio and ability to burn low cost fuels. A special combustion chamber was developed for the VIVIAN Diesel to give the greatest efficiency and immediate starting in any weather. Because of the ideal cooling and lubricating systems, and the large bearing surfaces, lubricating oil is also used in very small amounts.

Simplicity: The VIVIAN Diesel has been very carefully engineered to meet the requirements of the average operator, so that equally satisfactory results may be obtained whether the man be skilled or not, as long as reasonable limits of maintenance and operation are observed. Starting is effected by compressed air which is recognized as the most simple system available.

Compact Design: The compact construction of the VIVIAN Diesel allows a neat installation in a very small space. Large hand holes in each side of the base casting make it possible to reach internal parts easily.

In this line of engines there are six models, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8-cylinder sizes, each being 5½" bore by 8" stroke, and rated at 800 r.p.m. They are four stroke, solid injection, full Diesels and are of the single acting, vertical trunk piston, multi-cylinder design. This type of engine has the ability to effect perfect combustion at all speeds with ideal combustion cylinder walls, and excellent piston lubrication. VIVIAN Diesels have remarkably little liner wear and are free from bearing metal deterioration and overheated valves.

The engines are pleasing and neat in appearance, are completely sealed against dust, oil and fumes. They deliver continuous, dependable power, smoothly, flexibly, and with low operating and maintenance costs.

Base: In one piece, made of special cast iron, of substantial design with rigid transverse members.

Cylinder Block: Made of high test cast iron and is designed to provide great strength and rigidity without excessive weight. Large cover plates provide complete access to the main bearings and running gear. The upper part of the block is bored to receive the cylinder liners, the space between the frame and the liners forming the water jacket. The inlet water manifold and air manifold are formed integral in the block and large openings are provided for cleaning the water jacket space. The cylinder block also carries the camshaft which rotates in cast iron, bronze lined bearings. The camshaft assembly can be removed in one piece.

Cylinder Liners: Made of hard nickel alloy cast iron of special mixture developed for wearing quality. They are pressed into the block with a shoulder at the top. The lower end of the liner is guided in the block but the liner is free to expand, and water leakage is prevented by an adjustable packing gland and rubber packing. This construction prevents the possibility of distortion and greatly increases the life of pistons and rings.

Cylinder Heads: Nickel cast iron, cast singly, and carefully designed to give symmetrical arrangement of the valve openings and equal distribution of metal. Vertical overhead valves are employed and are operated through rocker arms, push rods, and tappets. The heads are easily removable without disturbing the exhaust manifold or other accessories.

Cylinder Head Covers: Made of cast aluminum and are readily removed for valve clearance adjustments. Removal of the cylinder head cover makes accessible the rocker arm assembly, valves and nozzle.

Crankshafts: Made of forged steel, annealed and heat treated. The bearings are large in diameter, and total area, with a main bearing on either side of each crankpin. This construction together with full proportioned webs provides rigidity to insure long life and freedom from frequent bearing adjustments.

Main Bearings: Consist of babbitted nickel cast iron bottom halves carefully fitted in a seat in the base and a cap of nickel cast iron lined with babbit. An extra bearing is fitted on each end of the engine, which adequately...

takes care of additional loads. These are the same as the others. Therefore, all main bearings are interchangeable.

Camshaft: Driven by spur gears at the front of the engine.

Connecting Rods: High grade steel forgings of ample length to insure low cylinder wall pressures and with marine type crank pin boxes of bronze lined with babbit. The wrist pin ends are forged solid, accurately bored, and fitted with oversize bronze bushings.

Pistons: Made of nickel cast iron suitable to withstand the high temperature and use of ample length. There is provision made to prevent lubricating oil from contacting the undersurface of the piston crown. A special VIVIAN feature is the shape of the top of the piston which forms the combustion volume. This is a highly developed and simplified design providing efficient combustion and immediate starting in any weather.

Piston Pins: High grade steel, hardened and ground, of liberal proportions and carefully fitted in the pistons.

Piston Rings: Six in number, five above the wrist pin and one below. The two bottom rings are of the oil scraper type.

Valves: The valves seat directly on the cylinder head, no cages or inserts being used. This arrangement is preferable as it gives maximum cooling of the valve heads and seats, and is permissible, as the complete head is not heavy and can easily be removed.

The exhaust and inlet valves are made of alloy steel stems with special high test nickel chrome alloy cast iron heads suitable to withstand the high temperatures. They are operated from the camshaft and are totally enclosed, but easily accessible.

Flywheels: Two flywheels are employed of sufficient weight to give the degree of uniformity of rotation required for the service for which the engine is used. Barring holes are provided in the rim of the front flywheel for turning the engine.

Valve Stem Guides: Made of cast iron and are renewable.

Exhaust and Inlet Valve Cams: Made of hardened steel.

Fuel Injection System: The fuel pump is a self-contained unit and individual cylinders and plungers for each cylinder are correctly timed, accurately meter the fuel, the amount being varied by the control rod. All plungers are operated from a common camshaft, and all adjustments are set and locked. The possibility of pump trouble of any kind is extremely remote. The pump is of the highest proven and interchangeability of the pump itself or its component parts has been fully provided for. The injectors are mounted on the cylinder heads and are well water-jacketed. They are of the automatic spring loaded plunger type with multi-hole nozzles which insure correct distribution of the fuel oil and efficient combustion. No adjustment on the fuel system is necessary or advisable.

Governor: A rugged but sensitive vertical type centrifugal governor maintains speed fluctuations within close limits. The governor is enclosed in a dust-proof, oil-tight housing and is gear driven from the camshaft. Linked to the governor is a horizontal rod which actuates the bypass mechanism of the pump, thereby metering the amount of fuel injected to suit the load, and controlling the speed within the closest limits.

Fuel Oil Filter: Designed to retain any abrasives which might be harmful to the fuel injection system.

Lubricating Oil Filter: Of simple and conventional design, is readily cleaned and easily accessible.

Water Pump: Bronze, gear type of ample size insuring positive volume.

Starting System: The engine is started by means of compressed air, the starting air being applied to all cylinders through a distributor. This distributor is of the rotary type, the rotating valve coming in contact with the seat only when the starting air is being applied, delivering air to the spring loaded poppet air valves located in the cylinder heads. The engine is fitted with a water-cooled air compressor driven from the crankshaft for charging the starting tank.

Exhaust Manifold: Made of cast iron and is water-jacketed when required. Connection is made to the cylinder head exhaust ports through an elbow.

Lubricating System: The lubricating system is of full pressure type to all principal bearing surfaces. The lubricating oil pump, which is a special gear driven rotary pressure pump, draws oil from the base through the lubricating oil filter to a main header, a branch from the header leading to each main bearing. The oil then passes through oil lines fixed in the crankshaft to each crankpin. It then passes upward through holes drilled in the connecting rods to the wrist pins. Other branches and headers supply oil under pressure to the camshaft bearings, governor bearings, rocker arms, push rod yokes and gear shafts. The pump is of more than adequate size supplying more oil than is necessary for all bearings and a relief valve is fitted which provides a flow of oil over the timing gears.

There are no separate oil cups or grease cups which need attention to take care of the main operating parts of the engine.

The air distributor and water pump assembly are provided with grease cups.

Cooling System: Full circulating pump system with distribution arranged to provide even temperature throughout the engine. From the discharge side of the pump, water passes through a main pipe cast in the cylinder block into the water jackets, and up through the cylinder heads, thence into the water-jacketed exhaust manifold from which it is piped to discharge.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on your inspection of the Kuper Island Indian residential school I note that you refer to the necessity of installing a new refrigeration system.

I should appreciate it if you would let me have detailed information regarding the refrigeration plant that you would suggest be installed in this school. Dear Sir:

Following our conversation over telephone when I was informed that a grant for a Manual Training building would not be provided by the Department, but that a sum to the amount of a suggested estimate would be provided for plumbing and improvements in a lavatory, I beg to acknowledge that without the Manual Training building the plans for the projected lavatory cannot be carried out, as the present Manual Training room was to be converted to a Lavatory.

I am however happy to say that the money which would have been affected to this purpose, would sufficiently defray the expenses for a series of Storage Batteries to replace the Power Batteries we have now which in a few months will have become quite useless.

Early in Spring I was able to realize that our present equipment was already inefficient and soon would have to be changed, but with difficult conditions prevailing together with fact that two estimates for this school had been sent to the Department, I thought it would be advisable to wait and let circumstances pave the way to a solution.

The cost of a new set of batteries as suggested by Marshall Wells, Vancouver would be $695.00 with discount from this price being 20%.

Hoping that the Department will not object to this request,

I am,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 20th instant, file No. above noted, regarding general repairs to the Kuper Island Indian Residential School, I wish to say that the remarks contained in Mr. Phelan's letter are noted; but I would respectfully point out that if funds are not available for the erection of the manual training building this year that the alterations on the basement, for which an amount of $600.00 is available, cannot be proceeded with owing to the fact that the manual training room at the present time is in the basement and until we have somewhere to move it to we cannot make the alterations in the basement.

I am, however, submitting herewith in duplicate a letter from the Reverend Principal of the School, which I trust you will find self-explanatory and which deals with the situation as it exists, pointing out that the condition of the batteries for the lighting plant is such that replacement is essential in the very near future and that the cost of a new set will amount to approximately $600.00. Yours obediently,

[R. H. Moore]
Indian Agent.

Sir:

As requested I made an inspection on May 24th of Kuper Island School building. Following is a report on conditions observed.

Complaints have recently been received by the Indian Affairs Branch from the School Principal, Rev. Father Camirand, that extraordinary settlement has taken place and an inspection and report was requested.

Kuper Island school was built in 1915, replacing a number of frame structures. The building is a two-storey brick-veneered frame structure on a concrete foundation. It appears to be substantially constructed except in a few details which will be reported on at length. It has been very well maintained. A photograph of the building is attached.

FOUNDATIONS

The concrete foundations extend to the first floor level, 10½ feet above the ground, and more than three feet below ground level (actual depth undetermined). There are said to be extended footings. The wall is 18" at the top and battered on the outside about 1 in 6 in the top six feet, being about 24 inches thick at ground level.

Close examination shows no sign of settlement. A few hairline cracks 3 or 4 feet in length appear in the plaster coating on the outside near the side entrances of the wings and at the front but
there is no marked separation at these points. Interior basement walls are of concrete, furred, lathed and plastered.

GROUND FLOOR

The ground floor level is well supported by wood-covered steel columns in the wings and front half of centre section. The rear half is supported by partitions. There is no evidence of settlement on the ground floor except in chapel ceiling where hanging rear wall has sagged about 1/4 inches. Separation along baseboards and wainscoating, ordinarily noticeable in frame buildings, is absent.

FIRST FLOOR

Only very slight unevenness at baseboards and wainscoating except at rear of centre section, above the chapel, where floor sag amounts to about 3/8 of an inch at rear wall. The building is divided by a partition at the centre, the left half being occupied by boys and the right half by girls. First floor is supported by partitions in centre section, by columns and partitions in wings. Only two floors in wings.

SECOND FLOOR

Unevenness in floors noticeable commencing at stair wells, both ends of centre section. Considerable sag immediately above chapel, separation of partition walls from rear wall and roof slope ceiling at several points. This is due to walls being pushed out of vertical by roof.
ATTIC

The sag noted on lower floors of the central section has accumulated in the attic ceiling and roof slopes. The apparent sag in second floor ceiling is about 2 to 3 inches; in the rear roof slope about 3 inches; in front roof slope about 1½ inches. Actual sag probably is considerably more if measured from the true apex line to eaves. A sag in the roof ridge is also noticeable from outside. The ceilings in both boys and girls dormitories on the second floor are carried on rafters and rafter ties supported by two trusses of 23½ feet span and 4½" rise.

The heavy cupola at the centre of the building is carried on the centre corridor walls. The roof, ceiling and floors directly beneath appear normal.

FRONT WALL

The front wall of the centre section is out of vertical about 1 inch inward along the front projection and out of vertical outward about the same amount at each side of the centre section from eaves to second floor level.

REAR WALL

The rear wall of the centre section is out of vertical outward about 2 inches from eaves to first floor level all along except at the chimney where it appears plumb, the chimney being apparently unaffected. A number of cracks appear in the brickwork above the line of the chapel roof. The separation along the mortar lines is about 1/4-inch. Several of these cracks have been filled. One, possibly of more recent occurrence, remains open. So far as could be deter-
mined there is no corresponding sag in the framework backing and the brick ties appear unaffected except possibly where the brick has sagged.

The Principal informs me that the sag in the top floor has been evident for many years but more recently there appears to have been an increase.

**CHAPEL**

There is a sag in the chapel ceiling directly under the hanging rear wall of the central section, amounting to about 1/4 inches. The sag no doubt accounts for the cracks in the brickwork above. There is also a noticeable sag in the slopes of the chapel roof. This is probably due to the fact that the ceiling is in part carried on the rafters. It was not possible to secure entrance to the space between the ceiling and roof of the chapel for examination. Indications of a slight leak in the corner of the chapel ceiling next the chimney were noted.

**WINGS**

The wings appear to be in very good condition. Unlike the central section there are columns and beams supporting the ground floor and first floor but none supporting the first floor ceiling. There is a slight sag in the ceiling.

Brickwork needs pointing in a few places, probably not exceeding 100 square feet altogether.

**CAUSE OF SAG**

The cause of sag in the ceiling and roof of the central section is insufficient support. This lack of support has in turn caused the outward thrust of roof components which forced the outside walls out of vertical.
RECOMMENDED STRENGTHENING

The accompanying sketches show suggested installations for adding support to roof and ceiling and to strengthen the outside walls.

In the case of the roof and ceiling support is to be provided by means of steel pipe columns based on the central corridor walls which are continuous to the basement floors. Beams supported on the columns are to be transverse to ceiling joist and carried through the dormitories to posts at partition walls. Ties are to be added between ceiling joist and rafters as shown in accompanying sketch.

It would be desirable to have an unimpeded floor surface in the dormitories but this could not be obtained except by the use of trusses. These would not be satisfactory even if suitably constructed as stable bearing points cannot be secured except by continuous columns carried up from the basement floor which would cause obstruction on other floors.

In order to strengthen the walls against the outward thrust of the roof, it is recommended that ties be placed at four points indicated on the sketches where lateral support can be provided against vibration so likely to be caused in the dormitories. Present ties seem to be inadequate in the top floor.

Two steel pipe columns are suggested for support of the beam in the chapel. These are to be carried on the basement walls. It will be necessary to shorten two pews about six inches in order to leave an unobstructed aisle.

The cost of the suggested repairs is estimated at $934.00. All wood columns in the dormitories
instead of steel would reduce the cost by about $100. While it is very likely the building will stand for many years without the suggested strengthening, I am of the opinion the designated supports should be installed. It will be evident in comparing the floor plans submitted (minor details omitted) of the building as found with those of the original design, that many changes were made which seriously impaired the strength of the structure. The probability of snow load, which is always a possibility on this coast and sometimes of very serious proportions for short durations, evidently was not contemplated when the upper floor and roof was built.

I do not believe there is any necessity to install beams and posts to support the ceiling of the first floor in the wings which have only a slight sag. Nor is there any urgency about strengthening the roof of the chapel which shows a noticeable sag. To do so would require a large expenditure. Such work could probably be more cheaply undertaken when the chapel requires a new roof.

WORK

It is very improbable that the walls and rafters can be brought back to their original positions. Whatever work of this nature is undertaken will need to be carefully done so as not to weaken the existing ties. Most of these are inaccessible for refastening without removal of much of the plaster on walls and ceiling.

The estimate for labour includes provision for some repairs to plaster, repointing of brick and painting, as well as the necessary carpentry work.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Indian Residential School,
Kuper Island, B.C.

Further to my memorandum to you of May 22nd last, with reference to the above, I may say that we have now been furnished with information dealing with conditions at the school as observed by Mr. Warren of Mr. Webb's staff during two inspection trips carried out on May 24th last and the 14th ultimo.

For your information and transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch, I enclose herewith duplicate copies of this report in which it is stated that the visible faults are of long standing, but have recently become worse. They are for the greater part confined to the central portion of the building.

In this connection, I may say that Mr. Warren has submitted prints of the existing layout of the various floors, and comparison with the original working drawings indicates many departures from the original design. The location of partitions has been changed, and a number of steel columns and beams designed as part of the structural frame have been added. No data is available regarding substitute measures adopted; but in view of Mr. Warren's report, it is considered likely that the central portion of the building has not been sufficiently braced, and the load imposed by the roof has spread the top of the front and rear back tensioned frame walls. This has caused separation of second floor partitions and floor construction, from the exterior walls, as well as having caused a spread in the roof members. This movement has resulted in sagging at the points mentioned in the report.

It will be observed that Mr. Warren considers repairs to the central portion of the building to be sufficient for the present. These repairs consist of providing additional support and stiffening for the roof construction, and by means of timber and turnbuckles securing the top of the exterior walls against further spread. Pipe column supports also appear to be required for the beam carrying the rear wall above the chapel roof.

Sir:

Re: Kuper Island School Repairs

I wish to report that the work recommended to be done at Kuper Island School in my report dated June 12, 1941, was completed August 31, 1941, except for painting on some fresh plaster which will be delayed until later in the year.

As it was desired to have the work completed during the school holidays, material originally recommended for use could not be obtained. Wooden columns were substituted for steel pipe columns and laminated wood beams were employed as dry timber of the dimensions proposed could not be obtained. Also, the material substituted was dry and was of equal strength to the original proposal. The attached sketch shows the strengthening added to the building.

The 3" steel tie rods used were anchored along the wall plate inside the cornice as shown in detail. The anchorage was carried through the brickwork only on the front projection. The space between the brick (about 1-5/8") and sheeting was packed to provide solid support. The rods were taken up to maximum tension but an attempt was made to bring the walls to a vertical position.

Plaster removed was replaced and a considerable amount of patching was done where painting at corners had occurred. All of the new woodwork was oiled and varnished.

A small amount of painting remains to be done on the new plaster, but this should be deferred for about six months. It is probable the school authorities will undertake this if the paint is supplied.

Some pointing of brickwork was done where cracks had occurred above the chapel roof and at several other points where spalling had occurred.

The cost of the work has not been determined yet, but will be given at a later date.

Attached hereto is a memorandum of inspection made at Kuper Island School of the water, electric lighting and sewage system during August and a sketch plan of the water system.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

While at Kuper Island School during August, I inspected the electric lighting system, water system and sewage disposal system. In this connection I wish to report as follows:

**ELECTRIC LIGHTING SYSTEM:** Electric lighting system consists of a direct current generating set housed in a frame building 12 x 14 feet detached from the school buildings.

Equipment consists of one Lister gas engine generator set 3 K.W., 110 volt, 550 R.P.M. This is part of what was originally a 2 unit Lister-Bruston automatic outfit installed about 1926. The larger of the two units has been replaced by a 35 H.P. Vivian Diesel engine with electric starter, belt connected to a 125 V., 15 K.W. C.G.E. generator installed in 1938. Both units are now manually controlled. Generator speed is 1,750 R.P.M., and the V-belt drive has 9" generator pulley and 25" engine pulley at 33½" o.s.

Lister plant has thermo-syphon cooling and the Vivian engine a circulating pump. A 56 cell Coyle storage battery of 180 amp. hrs. is also used, this was installed in 1940.

The plant appears to function satisfactorily. The Vivian engine which incidentally is much too large for requirements, was being overhauled at the time of my visit. The school Principal and the school mechanic appear satisfied with the operation of the plant. Cooling tanks appear to have a short life; it is possible that with a better grade of sheet metal longer life would be obtained.

Outside wooden cooling tanks would probably be preferable, on account of the longer life, but a larger capacity would be necessary than with metal tanks.

**WATER SYSTEM:** Domestic water is obtained from an underground spring about ¼ mile from the School. Water from the spring collects in a concrete lined pond, which in turn feeds a hydraulic ram. The ram pumps to an elevated tank which supplies water to the school by gravity. A further supply is derived from the pond by means of a gravity pipe line passing through a filter and thence to a concrete cistern of about 9,000 gallon capacity, at the rear of the power house. This supply is surplus to the requirements of the ram. From the cistern water is pumped to two pneumatic tanks in the boiler room of the school by means of an electrically driven displacement pump also in the boiler room, or alternatively to the high level tank to supplement the supply from the ram. The supply from the pneumatic tanks is primarily for fire protection service. The water system is shown on attached sketch.

**RAM:** A Columbia Hydraulic Ram #2 manufactured by Associated Engineering Corp., Portland, Ore., appears to be in good operating condition. Has 2" drive pipe about 125 feet long, and 1" discharge pipe about 1,150 feet long. Pumps about 2 gallons per minute, when operating efficiently. Pumping head about 70 feet, drive head about 11 feet.
FONDS: The spring is said to be 20 to 25 feet from the pond and connected by a 4" pipe, and stone filled drain. The pond is saucer-shaped about 50' x 80' with a maximum depth of about 5 feet. It is surrounded by a fence. There appears to be considerable loss from the spring and pond as evidenced by the wet ground immediately to the east. Many cracks are noticeable in the concrete pond lining. The loss would not appear to be important as a sufficient supply is said to be obtained by present means. Estimated flow of spring 15 to 20 g.p.m. The pond would appear to be unnecessary and a possible source of trouble. I have been told that at the time the school was built the flow of the spring was 60 to 70 g.p.m.

ELEVATED TANK: The elevated tank is located on a wooden tower 27 feet above ground level and about 350 feet from the school. Height of the tank above the basement floor level is about 50 feet. The wooden tank, 8 feet diameter and 6 feet high, has a capacity of about 2000 gallons. The roof is supported on the tower platform which is about 12' x 12'. The 1" feed pipe and 1" supply pipe to school are enclosed in a 12' x 12' wooden box filled with sawdust from tank to ground. There is also a 2" overflow pipe. The tower is built on concrete pedestals based on rock outcrop. The pedestals are on 12" crs. and 6" x 6" tower posts have 1 in 8 batter.

The tank and tower appear to be in good condition. Elevated tank is hardly high enough to give good service to upper floor of school when demand is heavy.

PNEUMATIC WATER SYSTEM: Pneumatic water system comprises two 4' x 20' steel tanks with an operating capacity of 1600 to 2000 gals. and a Meyers Bros., 913 M, 3" x 4" single cylinder pump with 13" suction and discharge, belt connected to a 1 H.P., 3 C. Motor. The rated capacity of this pump is about 15 U.S. gals. per minute against 100 lbs. pressure. This pumping system is intended primarily for fire protection purposes, but is used daily when the school is in session to supplement the ram supply to the elevated tank, by-passes being provided for that purpose.

At the time of my visit the pneumatic tanks appeared to be water-logged. This fact was called to the attention of the school Principal.

It should be noted that the pump capacity is only about 15 g.p.m.; this is insufficient for fire protection supply. Minimum pump capacity for this purpose should be 50 g.p.m. I was informed by the school Principal that it is intended to move the pump to the power house and have it belt-connected to one of the engines there. (This has since been done August 30.)

FIRE EQUIPMENT: Fire equipment consists of 2 hydrant outlets and 50' lengths of hose with nozzle on each of the four floors in the central part of the building. A fire axe in a case on each floor, and hand chemical fire extinguishers.

The building is equipped with outside fire escape stairways at the centre of each wing and slide poles at each rear angle of the building immediately adjoining the inside stair well. Access to all these escapes is through window openings.

August 25, 1941.

SEWAGE SYSTEM: The sewage system appears to be operating satisfactorily and there have been no complaints.

The system as first installed included a septic tank with an effluent pipe discharging into the sea. In 1931 a new sea outlet pipe was constructed to low tide and a by-pass of the septic tank provided. Since that time all of the sewage goes directly to the sea. The septic tank although still serviceable, is no longer used.

As you know the amount of $700.00 authorised for this purpose was not expended owing to the fact that we could not get the materials. The suggestion offered by Father Camirand is, to my mind, reasonable; the only catch being of course that the authority granted during the past fiscal year has expired and whether or not the Department will be able to provide an equal amount this year out of funds available, is, of course problematical.

Should such a thing be possible I would recommend that the Principal be given the authority to purchase the materials necessary, where, when and as he can find them, pay for them himself and then submit receipted accounts to me and I could attach same to regular vouchers. Dear Sir:

I beg to state that our Baker's oven is now so far gone that the cost of repairs appears to be prohibitive.

I have written to Hubbard Portable Oven Co., in Toronto, at two different times, requesting estimates for repair parts, as further investigation suggested need for more repairs, and their last letter advised that we purchase a new oven or a good factory-rebuilt oven rather than try to repair the old one. I was not aware when I first referred the matter to you that the wall had been built after the school had been in use for some years, just for convenience. AIR MAIL

Ottawa, June 19, 1945.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 13th instant, with reference to the purchase of a new engine for the boat operated by the Kuper Island Indian Residential School. In our appropriation for the fiscal year 1945-46 we made provision for an amount of $1,000.00 for the purpose mentioned.

Is it possible to secure a suitable engine in Vancouver? We have found it difficult to secure a boat engine in Eastern Canada. If you can obtain any quotations, please forward same for our consideration.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, November 28th, 1945.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

On June 19th last, I wrote you in reply to your letter of June 13th, with reference to the purchase of a new engine for the boat operated by the Kuper Island Residential School. At that time I advised you that in the Current Year's Appropriation there was an amount of $1000.00 available.

As yet we have not heard anything further from you. I presume that you have been unable to secure the engine. If you consider it unlikely that you can purchase it before the end of March I thought there might be some other equipment required at the school which could be purchased from the amount available. Under these circumstances I would appreciate hearing further from you.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Your File 152-0-5

I have to refer to Mr. Phelan's letter of June 19th, 1945, in connection with the proposed purchase of a new engine for the boat operated by the Kuper Island Indian Residential School. It was found impossible to obtain quotations for delivery of an engine within the current fiscal year and as an alternative, enquiries were made of the War Assets Corporation with a view to securing a new launch. Father Camirand, Principal of the school, located a suitable boat, approximately 26' long, good engine of Canadian make, at the Navy Yard in Esquimalt, which he considered would be very useful for the time being.

Subsequent correspondence with the War Assets Corporation indicates, however, that the launch in question has not been declared surplus and consequently is not yet available for disposal through the Corporation. It is thought, however, that the Department might be able to arrange for transfer of the launch direct from the Navy Yard to the Kuper Island Residential School, and it would be appreciated if enquiries could be made. I may say that the launch is identified by No. 243 B47 and is at present located at the Navy Yard in Esquimalt.

Mr. R. H. Moore

Dear Sir;

We are having a considerable amount of trouble with the sewage system, due to the fact that there is no outlet where various branches take on to the main, and that there is no possibility of forcing steam through with quick result, having to perform this operation at one or the other branch end, with the consequence that the contents are pushed back into lavatories and sinks.

There is no diagram or plan of the layout here available, and therefore no means of knowing where to break through the cement floor to get at the right location so as to make some kind of an outlet. I have asked for the prints but have not heard whether they are available.

As this happens most often on the boys side and also with the laundry sewage, it would seem that a separate sewage for these two would be required, and as the new lavatory for boys is about to be installed, this could be done before long. However this will require much labor and therefore expense as there would be need to dig through some six feet of hard clay, all the way from the building down to the water.

As Mr. Warren some years back supervised work anent a new lay out near water front, and probably has some idea of the general plan, may I suggest that if it appears in order, he be asked to come and examine possibilities of a separate sewage for laundry and boys lavatory.

May I state that in the last four months, this trouble has happened at least once every three weeks.

Yours very truly;

(Signed) Rev. J. Camirand.
Duncan, B.C.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Sewage Disposal, Kuper Island Indian Residential School

In accordance with your instructions an inspection of the sewage disposal works of the above institution was made on June 4. The purpose of this inspection was to determine the most advantageous connection of the proposed lavatory to the present sewage system. In this connection the following are my findings.

Description of the present system

The system, as originally constructed, consisted of a septic tank with a 6 inch drain from the school and a 4 inch pipe outlet into the sea. The main branches from various washrooms and lavatories in the school consist of 4 inch pipe. In 1931 the 4 inch outlet from the septic tank was abandoned and a new 8 inch outlet pipe was constructed. This new outlet by-passed the septic tank. The septic tank, although still serviceable, is no longer used.

This system worked satisfactorily until approximately a year ago when various branches, especially the one leading from the boys lavatory, began to clog up periodically.

Since the 4 inch branches leading from the various lavatories are of sufficient size for the population in the school, it appears that clogging is the result of the accumulation of sand, gravel, and other material in depressions caused by possible settling of various branches. The principal also reported that children, especially those starting school, were found on several occasions dropping fruit peels and rags into the drains.

Recommended connection of the proposed washroom or lavatory

Since the sewer branch, to which the showers, basins, and other equipment in the old lavatory are connected, passes by the room to be used for the new washroom, it appears that this new washroom or lavatory could be connected to the same sewer without any danger of exceeding the carrying capacity of the pipe. There will be approximately the same number of showers, wash basins, etc., in the proposed lavatory as in the present one.

It is recommended that some provision be made to facilitate cleaning of the sewer in case of future clogging in the proposed lavatory. This could be done in one of two ways:

Indian Affairs(RG 10 Volume 6456, file 835-5, part 5)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
(1) Installation of a check-valve and a tee in the branch leading from the lavatory. A hose could then be connected to the tee for flushing the sewer. The check-valve will prevent the water from backing up during flushing.

(2) Installation of a clean out chamber. This clean out chamber will then catch all the material such as large rags which otherwise would clog the sewer.

P.W. Strilacoff

Gentlemen,

On June 9th, we had a call from the Reverend Father at the Indian Residential School at Kuper Island, informing us that the lighting plant had broken down.

We dispatched a mechanic by plane to view the damage, which was extensive and comprised the following:

1. One cylinder liner broken
2. One piston broken
3. One Connecting Rod broken
4. One Bottom End Bearing broken
5. Crankshaft journal very badly scored and would not clean up
6. Side of Block broken
7. Main bearings worn and would probably have to be rebabbitted.
8. Other piston and rod should be replaced.
9. Should have valve grind and fuel injectors and pump checked.

This engine would have to be brought into our shop to repair.

The cost of repairing the engine would be approximately $1700.00 (including a new crankshaft).

As an alternative, we could supply a brand new modern engine from stock.

If the old engine is trade in and you will allow us to use the electric starting equipment, (which cannot now be obtained) from the U.S.A. in less than 6 months) the total cost to the Department would be $2500.00 for the new engine.

From our records the damaged engine has operated for over ten years with practically no maintenance or repairs.
The value, to us, of the damaged engine is little better than scrap value and we would strongly recommend the new engine.

Awaiting your instructions,

Yours very truly,

VIVIAN ENGINE WORKS LIMITED.

[Signature]

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Electrical System - Kuper Island Residential School, Cowichan Agency

Pursuant to your instructions, I made an inspection of the Kuper Island School electrical system. The following is a report of my observations.

Description

The school is a brick structure built in 1915. It houses approximately 112 persons during the school session. It is the only populated part of Kuper Island except for one farm on the southern end and an Indian Village on the northern end which is occupied spasmodically between fishing, lumbering, hop-picking, and berry-picking seasons.

Power House

Electrical power for the school is generated in a power house, separate from the main school, by a two cylinder 30 B.H.P. Vivian Stationary Diesel Engine driving a 15 KW 125 Volt C.G.E. direct current generator. Other installations included in the power house are (See Plan 1):

(1) Standby equipment 6 H.P. Lister engine driving a 3 KW Lister-Bruston 110 volt direct current generator.

(2) Myers water pump and reduction gear connected to the standby Lister engine.

(3) Battery of 55 Coyle cells - 120 volts.

(4) Switchboard panel.
Distribution System

The School is connected to the power house switchboard by an overhead line which runs into the building to fuse and distribution boxes. All lines inside are in conduit.

Served as well as the school are a woodwork shop, a barn, a recreation hall, and a house.

Additional to the lighting of the above mentioned buildings, there are several appliances served, namely:

1) 1/3 H.P. motor in the refrigerator fed by a direct line from the power house.

2) 1/2 H.P. motor in the Bakery fed off the school system.

3) 1 H.P. motor on a circular saw in woodwork shop.

4) Three hand irons in the laundry.

Capability of Present System

According to the engineer at the school, the maximum current generated at the switchboard when the diesel is running to capacity is 50 amperes. This is almost sufficient for the operation of the present system. However, the diesel vibrates considerably when running to capacity and its speed fluctuates enough to cause the lights to flicker. It should be noted that the 30 H.P. diesel engine should be able to drive the generator with almost twice the above mentioned load.

Discussion

The diesel engine was badly damaged in June of this year and requires repairs estimated by the maker to cost $1,700. Also, a new battery is needed.
which will cost $600. As this is a total expenditure of approximately $2,500., it has been suggested by the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia that consideration be given to converting the system to A.C.

Advantages of an A.C. System

(1) A.C. appliances and motors can be purchased easier and cheaper than similar D.C. This is not a great saving as the only additional appliances planned by the school staff are:

(a) Milking machine (probably requiring ½ H.P. driving motor).

(b) Additional equipment in woodwork shop (probably requiring two motors ½ to 1 H.P. and one of about 2 H.P.).

(c) One or two small appliances in the kitchen such as a potato peeler.

(2) If power is made available from the B.C. Power Commission at some future date, the conversion would be inexpensive. There seems little possibility of this change being made in the future because Kuper Island is at least four miles distant from the nearest point of land having electrical power.

Advantages of a D.C. System

(1) By using batteries in conjunction with the D.C. generator, lights can be used at any time during the day or night without the main engine being required. If batteries are not used, the engine will have to be run all the time or else be equipped with an automatic starter. During the night, lights are required periodically and often are left on by the Indian children, even though many attempts have been made to
stop this practice. This would result in the engine running almost continually even with an automatic starter.

(2) Light and some power are available from the batteries for some time after a temporary breakdown in the main engine.

(3) The cost of repairing the D.C. system although large is considerably less than the cost of a new A.C. system which would require new generators and motors in addition to the repairs to the diesel engine minus the $800. for new batteries.

Recommendation

It is the opinion of the undersigned that the D.C. system should be retained. Also it would seem advisable, if a new diesel engine is purchased, to have some guarantee beforehand from the maker that the engine will be capable of driving the 15 KW generator to full capacity.

The 15 KW generator can carry the present load in the school and as well could assume the future loads planned and already mentioned in this report.

D. Gordon.

Early in June the Principal of the Kuper Island Residential School contacted the Vivian Engine Works Ltd., advising that the diesel engine operating the generator at the school had broken down. Vivians dispatched a mechanic by plane to view the damage and subsequently reported to this office, reference their letter of June 10th attached. Copies of subsequent correspondence, namely Superintendent Moore's letters of June 14th and 21st, a quotation from Vivian Engine Works dated June 21st on a new engine and a copy of a report dated July 7th by Mr. D. Gordon of the Mines, Forests and Scientific Services Branch, together with Mr. C.E. Webb's covering letter are enclosed.

Also attached is a letter dated July 21st from Vivian Engine Works wherein they guarantee that the new engine quoted upon has more than ample power to drive the 15 K.W. generator at the school. You will note from the enclosures that we are faced with an expenditure of $2500. for a new engine and approximately $750.00 for new batteries for alternatively an expenditure of £1700. for repairs to the present engine, plus the cost of new batteries. The present engine is an obsolete model and according to Mr. Gordon's report does not develop its full rated power. This engine has been in operation at the school for over ten years with only minor expenditures for repairs. Its condition now is such that it has little, if any, trade-in
value and if repaired would likely be a source of continued trouble.

I would recommend that the Department approve the purchase of a two cylinder Vivian Stationary Diesel engine complete with all ancillary equipment and developing 30 B.H.P. continuous and 35 B.H.P. maximum in accordance with the Company's tender; and also purchase of a new VA-13 110 volt Glass Cell Battery as quoted on by Coyle Batteries Limited.

Fifty Years Ago...

The first Diesel Engine was so great a novelty that it was placed on public exhibition. Today, diesel powered, dependable source of power is "established" hard at work in factories, mines, quarries, ships, oil fields, fisheries, on farms and in many other industries.

Though the Diesel Engine was invented in Europe, Americans played the major part in introducing it. An American Diesel manufacturing company was organized only a year after the first diesel was built abroad. Within a few years, other American companies began to manufacture Diesel Engines. Today there are 15 companies building all types and sizes. Recognition came slowly, but demand rose during World War I when over 150,000 Diesel horsepower was in operation—chiefly aboard submarines.

Since then, Diesel power has gained worldwide acceptance. Up until end of 1943, 61,000,000 of Diesel horse-power had been built by the American industry. During World War II, the Diesel industry built over 50,000,000 horsepower for the armed forces.

What is a Diesel engine...and how does it operate?

OPERATING PRINCIPLE

There is nothing complicated or baffling about the operating principle of a Diesel Engine. It's simple enough to represent the highest achievement in thermal efficiency.

A cycle Diesel—such as the Shepard—is simpler in its operation than the engine in your car. The piston cycle is similar to that of the car's engine, but the complexities of an electrical ignition system and a carburetor are completely eliminated.

Here are the 4 simple cycles of the usual Diesel operation: (1) First piston downstroke. Clean air is "sucked" into the cylinder. (2) First upstroke. The air in the cylinder is compressed to 1/15th space it normally occupies. This great compression raises air temperature to about 1,000° F. At the peak of this upstroke, fuel oil is sprayed into the heated air. The heat of the air instantly ignites the oil. (3) Second downstroke. Combustion of the fuel increases pressure and temperature in the cylinder forcing piston upward. This is the stroke that provides power and is known as the "power stroke." (4) Second upstroke. Exhaust is forced out. And because a Sheephead Diesel is equipped with an exhaust muffler, relatively harmless. In the completion of this stroke, cylinder is ready to repeat combustion cycle.

SIMPLICITY OF OPERATION

The absence of an electrical ignition system and a carburetor makes a Diesel engine easy to operate and maintain. To start a Diesel simply open throttle for desired engine speed and press the starter button. There's no distributor or spark plug points to be kept clean...no carburetor to be properly adjusted. Damp weather and rain has little effect on the starting and operation of a Diesel. Most of the smaller engines can be serviced by anyone familiar with a gasoline engine. With a minimum of attention a Diesel will give a maximum of dependable day-after-day operation.

ECONOMY OF OPERATION

The chart at left compares the fuel consumption of a conventional Diesel with that of the gasoline engine which it replaced. The Diesel uses only about 1/3 the amount of fuel at approximately 1/3 the cost per gal. We will gladly furnish complete details and location of this installation upon request.

THE HEART OF EVERY DIESEL

A Diesel Engine cannot perform better than its fuel injection system. It is the heart of every Diesel. After all, Diesel power is simply the result of burning oil under special conditions. How the oil is delivered to the combustion chamber...and what the combustion chamber does with it...determines the answer to the question, "How efficiently and economically will my Diesel Engine utilize fuel?" If your Diesel is a Sheppard, you'll get the answer you like. No part of a Sheppard Diesel is here more painstakingly designed, engineered and constructed than the fuel injection and combustion system.

The simplified Sheppard fuel injection system

The Sheppard Diesel is a solid fuel injection type engine. The fuel is ignited entirely by the heat of compression.

In the Sheppard Diesel, an individual fuel pump serves each cylinder connecting directly to the injector nozzle. If specified at time of purchase, provision can be made for changing pumps without shutting down operation. The fuel enters the pump and the injection timing is controlled by the pump. The 3 valves employed in the system are simple check valves...no pressure valves are necessary.

Like the combustion chamber, the Sheppard Diesel Fuel Injection System is an engineered integral unit. The entire system—including fuel injection pump, injector, combustion chamber and governor—was designed and engineered by Sheppard and is manufactured in the Sheppard factory.

The Fuel Pump. The fuel pump is of the variable stroke type and is entirely a Sheppard product—both in design and manufacture. It is not necessary to run new pumps in order to calibrate it...in fact, it can be done with the engine running.

The Injector Nozzle. To eliminate the faults of complicated foreign systems, Sheppard designed their own injection equipment and combustion chambers. And because they were designed simultaneously...to work together...Sheppard is able to use an injector nozzle with a very large orifice—thus eliminating nozzle stoppage.

In the Sheppard Diesel, fuel is discharged into the combustion chamber in a very coarse spray or stream. In this chamber, the fuel is broken into minute particles of the proper size for combustion. Efficient lubrication is provided throughout the combustion chamber walls. As a result, there is no carbon deposit and excess smoke is eliminated at all loads.

The Combustion Chamber. With the Sheppard fuel system, the fuel is injected directly into a special pre-combustion or turbulence chamber. From this chamber, the gases, during expansion, pass into the cylinder. Chamber walls are designed to be three passages of different diameters and divergent angles.

A layer of air, entering the chamber at high velocity from these passages, at time of injection, provides immediate ignition of the fuel against the wall of the combustion chamber. This creates an optimum of turbulence which produces thorough, rapid, highly efficient combustion without smoke. Detonation is eliminated...Diesel knock is absent.

GOVERNOR. Of simple, rugged construction, the Sheppard governor provides extremely close regulation to within 1/2% and maintains speed regulations within minute limits over long periods of time. Engine RPM's under load are maintained to within 1% tolerance. The ability of the Sheppard governor to maintain a constant speed at either constant or varying loads is outstanding. Because Sheppard precisely controls travel well, diesel engines are ideal for electrical applications. When used as power units, 2 or more engines can be belted to one shaft with equal distribution of load on each engine.
Removable Wet Type Cylinder Liners. These removable liners are made of special close-grained hardenable iron with a BHN of 500. They are honed to cross-hatch finish on the inside. Scaffolding rings never occur. The head holds the liner in place and the head gasket seats it at the top. Bottom is sealed by a special Sheppard-designed rubber gasket that absorbs shock from loadings into the crank case. Liners are designed to allow for expansion without creating stress or distortion in either the block or the liners themselves.

Completely Automatic LOAD-CONTROL Developed by Sheppard engineers and available on any Sheppard Diesel Generating Set. LOAD-CONTROL provides automatic starting and stopping of the Diesel by load demand on the power circuit. No special wiring is required. Operating time of Diesel is controlled by the load during normal operation. Normally required fuel consumption is reduced...engine life is lengthened. Power is turned on instantly...at instant of shut off...by the flick of any switch on the power circuit. Load control is available on any single or 3-phase Sheppard generating set if specified at time of purchase.

Built-in Heat Exchanger and Expansion Tank. On Sheppard marine units, the expansion tank and heat exchanger are located in the engine itself as one unit. This eliminates the maze of external piping and tubing required on most Diesel heat exchanger installations. By using the expansion tank below the heat exchanger tubes, corrosion and any necessary cleaning can be done without losing the fresh water. Tube nest can be removed for replacement or repair by loosening 2 additional bolts on any forward body while the pump is running. The water pump will also pass through the exchanger because openings in the tubes are of the same diameter as those in the pump and piping.

Oil Bath Air Cleaner has been designed and developed after years of research and development. Air enters the unit clean through a patented metal-side vent. Vent openings are large enough to permit free air passage—but small enough to exclude leaves or other foreign matter. Air then passes through a series of oil-washed screens which remove any particles that may have survived the oil bath. When air enters intake manifold, it is virtually 100% free of dust and grit.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Electrical System - Kuper Island Residential School, Cowichan Agency

Pursuant to your instructions, I made an inspection of the Kuper Island School electrical system. The following is a report of my observations.

Description

The school is a brick structure built in 1915. It houses approximately 112 persons during the school session. It is the only populated part of Kuper Island except for one farm on the southern end and an Indian Village on the northern end which is occupied spasmodically between fishing, lumbering, hop-picking, and berry-picking seasons.

Power House

Electrical power for the school is generated in a power house, separate from the main school, by a two cylinder 30 B.H.P. Vivian Stationary Diesel Engine driving a 15 KW 125 Volt C.G.E. direct current generator. Other installations included in the power house are (See Plan 1):

(1) Standby equipment 6 H.P. Lister engine driving a 3 KW Lister-Bruston 110 volt direct current generator.

(2) Myers water pump and reduction gear connected to the standby Lister engine.

(3) Battery of 55 Coyle cells - 120 volts.

(4) Switchboard panel.
Distribution System

The School is connected to the power house switchboard by an overhead line which runs into the building to fuse and distribution boxes. All lines inside are in conduit.

Served as well as the school are a woodwork shop, a barn, a recreation hall, and a house.

Additional to the lighting of the above mentioned buildings, there are several appliances served, namely:

(1) 1/3 H.P. motor in the refrigerator fed by a direct line from the power house.

(2) 1½ H.P. motor in the Bakery fed off the school system.

(3) 1 H.P. motor on a circular saw in woodwork shop.

(4) Three hand irons in the laundry.

Capability of Present System

According to the engineer at the school, the maximum current generated at the switchboard when the diesel is running to capacity is 50 amperes. This is almost sufficient for the operation of the present system. However, the diesel vibrates considerably when running to capacity and its speed fluctuates enough to cause the lights to flicker. It should be noted that the 50 H.P. diesel engine should be able to drive the generator with almost twice the above mentioned load.

Discussion

The diesel engine was badly damaged in June of this year and requires repairs estimated by the maker to cost £1,700. Also, a new battery is needed.
which will cost $800. As this is a total expenditure of approximately $2,500., it has been suggested by the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia that consideration be given to converting the system to A.C.

Advantages of an A.C. System

(1) A.C. appliances and motors can be purchased easier and cheaper than similar D.C. This is not a great saving as the only additional appliances planned by the school staff are:

(a) Milking machine (probably requiring ½ H.P. driving motor).

(b) Additional equipment in woodwork shop (probably requiring two motors ½ to 1 H.P. and one of about 2 H.P.).

(c) One or two small appliances in the kitchen such as a potato peeler.

(2) If power is made available from the B.C. Power Commission at some future date, the conversion would be inexpensive. There seems little possibility of this change being made in the future because Kuper Island is at least four miles distant from the nearest point of land having electrical power.

Advantages of a D.C. System

(1) By using batteries in conjunction with the D.C. generator, lights can be used at any time during the day or night without the main engine being required. If batteries are not used, the engine will have to be run all the time or else be equipped with an automatic starter. During the night, lights are required periodically and often are left on by the Indian children, even though many attempts have been made to
stop this practice. This would result in the engine running almost continually even with an automatic starter.

(2) Light and some power are available from the batteries for some time after a temporary breakdown in the main engine.

(3) The cost of repairing the D.C. system although large is considerably less than the cost of a new A.C. system which would require new generators and motors in addition to the repairs to the diesel engine minus the $800. for new batteries.

Recommendation

It is the opinion of the undersigned that the D.C. system should be retained. Also it would seem advisable, if a new diesel engine is purchased, to have some guarantee beforehand from the maker that the engine will be capable of driving the 15 KW generator to full capacity.

The 15 KW generator can carry the present load in the school and as well could assume the future loads planned and already mentioned in this report.

D. Gordon.

Re: Estimates for 1949-50.

Replying to your above noted letter I wish to report as follows:

1) The necessity of a Launch for use at the Kuper Island Residential School has been stressed on various occasions by the writer. The present Launch which is owned by the school is certainly not a suitable craft in which to transport Indian children to and from the school. In my opinion the launch is unsafe except in fine weather and calm seas. My opinion of what is required is something like this:

28' to 32' in length with a minimum beam of 8'; 3½' draft and powered with a 70 to 90 H.P. Gray or Kermath Marine Motor. The cabin should extend the full length of the boat with a partition a little forward of midships with the upper part of the partition in glass so that the operator of the boat could supervise the back cabin which would be for passengers - front of the partition to be engine room and pilot house.

The Present Launch is 26' long with a 6' beam and I would not advise spending any money on it.

The Principal is away low on his estimate of the cost of a Launch of this kind and what is required. Personally I think it should be closer to seven thousand dollars ($7,000.00) and would ask that you raise the price on the estimate forms to that amount.

The only alternative to the above, as I see it, is for the Department to pay the transportation to and from Chemainus Hospital when pupils are taken over there for medical attention and X-Rays, and also the transportation of all children going to and coming from the school throughout the school year.

2) The necessity for a barn at this school is obvious and urgent to anyone who has seen the present one which is so old that it is not a fit building to house cows that are supplying milk to an institution of this kind.

At the present time this barn houses fourteen to sixteen milch cows, three or four head of young stock, three horses and one bull. The swine are kept in a separate building which is also on its last legs.

The actual farm connected with the school has an acreage of 72. This is all under cultivation or in pasture with the exception of twelve or fourteen acres in playground and building site. The actual division this year is as follows: 3 acres potatoes; 1 acre in roots; 4 acres in corn; 2 acres in garden; 7 acres in oats; 22 acres in hay; 20 acres in pasture.

The old barn is 80' x 41' x 18' high, with hay loft. About twelve feet are taken off the length by a driveway through the middle for unloading hay, etc., into the loft.

I believe that a new barn, 70' x 35' x 40' would be satisfactory but even that would cost a minimum of twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00). I am not

Dear Sir:

You will recall that July last, I was advised that the sum of $2000.00 would be available for maintenance and repairs at this school, and also that previously, when going over Estimates, the need of having the school painted was considered urgent, as this had by force been neglected during the war years.

With money available I immediately took steps to have the roof, at least, stained, as it was leaking in several places, it being evident that without attention for another year, the shingles would no longer hold where most weather-beaten. A contractor was approached and estimate of cost submitted.

Contractors made all preparations to begin work, first week in August, and therefore paint was ordered and delivered, and another job was put off to meet obligation. Shortly before work was to begin, word was received that because the cost of a new engine and batteries for the school would exceed the amount actually provided in the year's appropriation, money would not be available for the painting.

In view of the fact that the Contractors were greatly put out, and more so because the painting was very urgent, I had the work done, with the hope that since the work had to be done some time or other, consideration would be given in regard to the amount expended and reimbursement made possible, and for this reason I beg to submit in triplicate the statement of the Contractors which are here-with.

Memorandum

Re: Fire Escapes; Kuper Island Residential School, Cowichan Agency, B.C.

Replying to your marginal note of June 10th on memorandum from the Director of Indian Affairs, dated June 9th, requesting an inspection of fire escapes at the above school, which are reported to be unsatisfactory, may the following comments on the subject of emergency exits, be considered.

Practically all these old schools have exits through windows, the sills of which are at various heights above the floor, in some cases as much as four feet in dormitories. The method of descent, in many cases, is by an iron pole from a structural steel landing at each floor. Obviously this method of descent is impracticable for small children. In addition, our experience in investigating these exits has been that the windows of dormitories leading to emergency exits have been nailed up or padlocked to prevent the older children from making unauthorized departures. The use of steel stairs in lieu of poles does not seem to be any solution where small pupils must descend several stories under winter conditions.

Modern practice is to build a stair of noncombustible materials within a fireproof enclosure or tower, properly lit and having entrances from each floor. These towers can be used as ordinary stairs, and should be located at each end of the building by means of which the whole school pupilage and staff may leave the building with maximum speed and complete safety.

Where fire escape stair towers cannot be added to an existing school, an effective type of fire escape would be a steel chute for buildings not over three storeys in height. The exits to these chutes should be from a door or window which would not impede the exodus of pupils and be in a straight line to the ground. By no means should a circular chute be considered.

This type of fire escape would be costly and depending on the school would probably occupy more space than is usually considered desirable. Furthermore if any fire escape is to serve the purpose in an emergency, entrance thereto must be unobstructed at all times.

The Indian Affairs Branch will no doubt appreciate the reasons behind our recommendations. If they are prepared to undertake the construction of steel escape chutes for the above school, this Division will prepare a design and obtain estimates of cost from our field officers.

Chas. H. Buck,
for Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

Director,
