Webb in his letter of July 14th, 1943, copies of which you received on June 20th, 1943, along with a copy of my letter to the Department (your file 3-11-1) also the report of Dr. T. S. Mills dated August 3rd, 1943, copy of which you may not have received but Dr. Tempest has a copy which you might read if you think necessary. Mr. Inspector Davey is conversant with the necessary alterations which should be carried out in dormitories and girls' recreation room.

Under date of August 4th, 1943, a letter was received from the Department, file number 152-0-5 (21), with copy of memo attached from Mr. T. S. Mills, Chief Engineer, Ottawa. However, so far as I know nothing further was done by the Engineering Branch in Vancouver who were obviously the people to supply the information requested by Mr. Mills.

You will, of course, recall the repairs and improvements recommended recently by the Boiler Inspector for boilers number 22620 and 22563 at this school as well as to the heating plant. (see your letter April 28th, 1943). If these repairs and renewals are to be made there will be nothing left from the amount authorized by the Department for anything else.

I should like to say that the Kuper Island Indian Residential School has been financially "starved" insofar as annual appropriations are concerned for the past ten years and I am concerned as to what the outcome will be unless early action is taken to provide sufficient funds to do some of the most pressing work and do it right. Where we have to put a few dollars here and there each year to keep the place operating is, in my opinion, poor economy. As I see it at the moment all our grant this year - of $200.00 - will be used up in the boilers and heating system leaving nothing for any other necessary expenditures.

Please understand that I am not trying to be critical but rather to bring the situation to the attention of the Department so that embarrassment may be avoided should conditions get serious -- particularly in the health of the pupils. The suggestion of cutting down the enrollment is not desirable as the cost of operation of a small school (100 pupils) is much higher in proportion than one with twice that enrollment -- hence part of the difficulty, financial, would be further aggravated.

I regret that I was unable to discuss this matter with Mr. Davey last week owing to his absence but wonder if he could take the time to run over to Kamloops some morning where I would meet him and go into the situation -- no need for us to go to the school unless the Inspector may think it advisable.

Dear Mr. Moore:

Herewith find details of suggestions and quotations as made direct to the Rev. J. Cominard, at the Ender Island Indian School, in our letter of May 17th, 1949.

As requested we have made a general survey of the existing installations in connection with suggestions as pointed out by yourself and Mr. G. Hallsell, the Dominion Boiler Inspector, as to improvements.

The return system of the existing pipe installation on the heating boiler is very sluggish owing to the pipe hookup and limited head room between top of boiler and ceiling. For the installation of a condensate pump as recommended by handling existing net radiation load of approximately 5000 feet of 2" 6-1/3 Pipes & Powers condensate pump or equal would be required. The cost of this particular section of alteration work in supplying and installing the piping, fittings and incidentals would be $675.00 (Six Hundred and Seventy-five Dollars).

At the present time the domestic hot water is heated through the medium of a coil in the heating boiler during the winter months and a jacket heater during the off heating season. This particular jacket heater is very impractical for your use as it was designed for burning coal while the main fuel supply for your school is wood. From the information we have the coil in the boiler is from fifteen to twenty years old and therefore may give out at any time. Neither the hot water storage tank or the circulating pipes are insulated which creates a great heat loss.

To obtain an adequate supply of hot water during the heating or winter season we would suggest installing a Head Side Arc Heater complete with motorized valve for automatically controlling the temperature of water in the storage tank, insulation for storage tank, sidearm heater and recirculating pipes to be fibreglass at a completed cost of $498.50 (Four Hundred Ninety-eight Dollars and Fifty Cents).

For spring, summer, and fall use we recommend a suitable hot water heater for burning wood which we could have made up in Nanaimo. This would be a steel drum type furnace with copper coils fitted horizontally in the upper part of the cylinder. Furnace would be fitted with firebox, ash door and wood burning grates and would be sufficiently long to handle 36" wood.

As an alternative to this, steel jacketed boiler could be made up. This would be cylindrical in shape set on the horizontal which would eliminate the necessity for coils at approximately the same cost as the above. As this is a low pressure water system it could be operated quite satisfactorily equipped with the regulation relief valve which is non-existent on the present system. For a complete job as outlined above the cost would be $345.00 (Three Hundred and Forty-five Dollars).

We might also suggest that it would be possible to supply a vertical type oil burner unit using diesel oil with a H. G. Little oil burner using a 55 gallon drum on a gravity line at a cost of $365.00 (Three Hundred and Sixty-five Dollars).
The estimated cost of materials for necessary repairs and replacements would include 36-1/2" steam traps with tail pieces suitable for the job, 12-1" steam radiator valves with the proper packing glands, 3-3/4" Steam Air vents. The whole system would have to be checked over if proposed alterations are carried out and all traps cleaned, repaired or replaced. An allowance of $75.00 (Three Hundred Seventy-five Dollars) should be allowed for this part of the work on time and material basis.

In regard to storage tank which supplies hot water to kitchen and two bathrooms, this has a very poor piping connection on recirculating lines besides the tank is not insulated resulting in a very poor supply of hot water. We would recommend rewiring the recirculating lines, insulate tank and pipe lines and supply and install suitable approved automatic relief valve. The cost of this work would be $135.00 (One Hundred Thirty-five Dollars).

We have based the above mentioned prices on the assumption that transportation would be provided to and from Kuper Island. Cost of boarding the men has not been included in quotations but would be based on the prevailing rate of $5.00 per day per man in this area, or a total cost of $72.00. If desirable board and room could be provided by the Department, otherwise it would be charged against the job and paid by us.

Respectfully submitted,

Rv H. ORMOND

Further detailed study has been given to the alteration or replacement of the pole fire escapes and we find that replacement by wooden stairs enclosed in fire resisting timber towers will be a somewhat costly undertaking, as well as defacing the appearance of the building. Furthermore, the existing structure is not constructed so as to make the erection of steel chutes a practical solution.

It is felt that the removal of poles and the erection of steel stairs and additional landings should provide an adequate and safe means of exit. The normal snowfall in the district in which the school is located, according to the meteorological service records, is between six and twelve inches in the month of January, with much less in the other winter months. Under these circumstances, it is felt that to undertake the construction of enclosed stairways is unnecessary.

Mr. C.E. Webb has been asked to obtain tenders for alterations and additions to the existing fire escapes based on details shown on the enclosed blueprint.

We have not shown any interior alterations but would point out that access to the two end wall fire escapes are through rooms designated on the original plans as "Monitor".

The National Building Code is quite clear that access to fire escapes shall be from hallways or corridors through doors at floor level, and to meet this requirement it is recommended that the corridor be extended to exit doors and the monitor rooms, if required, be re-located adjoining the corridor and extending into the existing dormitories.

Attached is a letter from the Reverend Principal of the above mentioned school in which he requests consideration for a grant towards the purchase of a tractor, along with a letter in support of this request from Superintendent Moore.

The need for such a machine is adequately covered in the above mentioned letters. It will be noted that this request arises from the necessity of replacing the team of horses used on the school farm. The school's share of the cost of the tractor will approximate $1,000, which is greatly in excess of the amount which would be required to replace the team, and it is felt that this will adequately meet the regulations outlined in the Department's circular letter of June 21, 1948 concerning the supply of farm equipment, and the considerable advantage of the tractor over the team of horses justifies the Department's approval of a grant of $750.00 towards the purchase of this new piece of equipment, as recommended in Mr. Moore's letter.

I might add that we are aware of the Department's policy with regard to the supply of tractors to residential schools but feel that in British Columbia some exceptions should be made, particularly in those cases such as Kuper Island where the available agricultural land is insufficient to produce the garden produce required for the pupils, feed for the milk cows and feed for horses to work the land.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
W.S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Commissioner for B.C. Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Kuper Island Residential School.

In reply to your above letter and further to mine of August 12th and 16th last, I wish to advise after all known commitments are taken care, insofar as a new heating and hot water system for the school is concerned as well as materials for the manual training building, an approximate amount of $900.00 will be available for other purposes at the school and previously listed, out of the total sum of $4100.00 approved for this school.

In discussing this with the Rev. Principal when we were trying to decide which would be the next item in order of priority that should be done, the question of the farm came up and the necessity for the purchase of three horses as the present ones are so old and crippled that they are no longer of any use. The principal is confronted with either buying a new team or a small tractor. The latter is certainly more economical than the horses, largely I think owing to small acreage available at the school as well as the high cost of feed and freight. The saving in feed for horses will more than provide enough for two extra cows which are badly needed so that more milk and butter may be available for the pupilage. The labor saving will also be considerable and all to the good of the children. During all the years that I have been here this school has been operating from hand to mouth and at an annual financial loss. This has resulted in less food and clothing for the children which has been severely criticized on many occasions, as well as insufficient staff.

In view of the fact that the Principal will provide funds to pay the major share of the tractor and plow, I would ask that the Department stretch a point in this instance and allow an amount of $750.00 to be made available to assist the Principal in making the purchase of the tractor which will cost about $1700.00.
I know that supplying tractors to Residential schools may not receive favourable consideration by the Department owing to the fact that the School is supposed to provide this equipment from their own funds, which is reasonable providing the school was financially able to do so. However, Kuper Island school is not economically sound and never will be owing to its location, small area of land suitable for agriculture and costly to get supplies and pupils to and from the school.

For the above reasons I would recommend that we assist the Principal to an amount as mentioned in paragraph 3 of this letter.

A letter in duplicate from the Principal is attached hereto and which will be found self-explanatory.

R.H. Moore,
Superintendent.

Dear Sir:

I understand there are some nine hundred dollars left for repairs and improvement at this school, the cost of repairs and work on the furnace and cost of material to complete Manual training shop having been deducted from the total appropriation for this fiscal year.

In view of the fact that I am now obliged to replace the team of horses, old and not matched, may I suggest that the Department consider investing the said nine hundred dollars in a tractor complete with double plow, as part payment of a total cost of seventeen hundred dollars, it being the responsibility of the school to pay off the balance and to pay for any equipment needed later.

I am well aware that it is not the policy of the Department to purchase farm operating items, as indicated in a circular of June 21st 1946, but I feel that my request as stated may be justified by the following reasons:

The service of a tractor would lessen the cost of labor as the heavy work would be done in less time, and one farm help would be equal to doing all the extra chores besides, whereas with horses, the time factor being considered, there is need of extra help, as now the boys are no longer available, being in the classroom all day; and this cost of extra labor being less over a period of one year, the balance of the cost would be almost paid off. Subsequently there would still be a saving, and this could be utilized for the purchase of more food and clothes, two items which are the object of frequent criticism.

There would be a benefit in this also that two more cows could be fed with what it takes to feed two horses, and therefore more milk and byproducts made available for the children. It is to be noticed that the cost of feed presently is very high and made more so through the added cost of transportation due to the unusual location of the school. There will indeed be a cost for the transportation of gas, but a great deal less as the service station is nearby.

A third reason is that the acreage is not large enough to supply hay and root crops in sufficient quantity for the year; as it is we grow more hay than root crops and therefore have to buy concentrates at exorbitant prices to make up for what is wanting, added to this again the price of transportation, which of course would be greater for hay, had we to buy same, than for feed. With two horses less to feed, the improvement in this respect is obvious.

Finally as to the funds that will be made available to pay off balance of purchase, I feel that these will accrue from less expenditure for fire wood, due to the fact that there will be a power-take-off on the
tractor; and with the saw we have already will be in a position to cut our own wood at a saving of three dollars per cord, two hundred cords being needed for the year.

I trust the Department will view the purchase of a tractor as a very great help for this school and will consider my sincere request.

Yours truly

J. Camirand
December 12th, 1949.

Re: admission of a child to Kuper School.
Gaspard Elliot, child of a half-breed father and an
Indian mother, who were never legally married, was admitted
to Kuper Island School, in April or May, 1935. The Principal,
not knowing the exact status of the child, referred the case
to the Agent, who said the child would have to be dismissed.
Meantime the child's father went to the school to claim the
child. The Principal told him that the child was his and that
he could take him at once. But the father refused to take him,
saying that he would be back soon to get him. He never came
for him and so the Principal sent the child to his mother.
I was asked to take up the matter by the mother who since a
few years is the sole supporter of the child, being separated
from her husband.

I spoke to the Agent about it, who told me that
the child could not be admitted to any Indian School, being a
half-breed, and could not go to Kuper specially as it was
against the will of his father. As to be admitted to an
Indian School, I know that some of his cousins, Elliots and
half-breeds also are attending the Chilliwack School. The
Principal at Kuper Island is willing to accept the child,
as long as a decision would be given by the Department. As
I was told that it was by special request that the Elliots
were admitted at Chilliwack, I made the same request for
this child, and a sister of his who never attended school.

As to go against the will of his father, may I
ask for a decision from the Department. The mother was
allowed to have her children baptized as Catholic. She is
the only one looking after them now.
Ottawa, August 13, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter with reference to the admission of a child, named Gaspard Elliot, to the Kuper Island Indian Residential School.

We do not appear to have received any correspondence from you regarding this boy.

We are informed that the mother is the sole support of the child, and, under these circumstances, it is considered that the boy is eligible for admission to the school which she requests him to attend.

The Department would therefore appreciate if you would arrange to have an application form and certificate of health for his admission to the Kuper Island School submitted for our early consideration.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
For Supt. of Indian Education.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duncan, B.C.
Sir:

In reference to yours of the 13th, instant, I would say that Gaspard Elliot, is a son of Henry Elliot, half-breed and of Sophie, daughter of Joe Whullwhalatza of the Chemainus Band.

Henry Elliott has deserted Sophie, who now has the child, and I understand is applying for admission to the Kuper Island School, as this child would have no ways or means of obtaining any education, unless allowed to attend the Kuper Island Residential School, I would like to have the Department's sanction covering the admittance of this child, and then have the admittance papers duly made out.

Your obedient servant,

(H. Graham)
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, August 31, 1936.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 24th instant, please forward, for the Department's file, application and certificate of health for the admission of Gaspard Elliot to the Kuper Island Indian Residential School. If the boy is pronounced medically fit by the doctor, he may be placed in the school at once.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your radiogram of the 13th instant with reference to 6 truants from the Kuper Island Indian residential school.

The Department is at a loss to understand why the Acting Indian Agent requested the Provincial Police to return these boys to the school. It should have been possible for the Acting Indian Agent himself to locate these boys and return them to Kuper Island.

It is noted that you have arranged to send Inspector Barry to the school for a special inspection and when a report is received you will no doubt forward a copy to me.

Yours truly,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

This Branch is in receipt of a radiogram dated January 12 and a letter and report dated January 19 from Major D. N. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, British Columbia, in both of which communications he reports the absence without permission of six students from the Kuper Island (R.C.) Indian Residential School, Cowichan Agency, British Columbia.

These pupils, who escaped from the institution in a canoe, were later found safe at home or with friends on the adjoining reserves. Conditions at the Kuper Island School and the charges made by these boys that they were harshly treated are now under consideration by Inspector Barry. A full report of Captain Barry's investigation and Commissioner MacKay's comments thereon will reach this Branch in due course.

Director.

Duncan, B.C.
April 18th, 1939.

I am writing you in connection with the application for admission to the Kuper Island Indian Res. School of Arnold Recalma, the son of Martha Recalma and Indian girl of the Qualicum Band of Indians. It would appear as if there is a full brother of this boy already in the school, having been admitted under date of August 17th, 1935 and shown on the role of that School as #443. His admission was approved in Official letter #152-0-10 dated October 19th, 1935.

It would appear as if both these boys are illegitimate sons of the same white man, name unknown and Martha does not want to divulge it, although she says he is a married man.

The children have lived with the mother ever since they were born and apparently the father has done nothing towards their support, so to all intents and purposes they are living the life of Indians and will probably continue to do so.

However, I quite appreciate the fact that later in their life one or the other of them may wish to be cut off the Indian list, and then explanations would have to be made to the Department, so I deem it advisable to inform you now.

As the mother (Martha) is very anxious that these boys should go to school-Kuper Island-I am of the opinion that it might be well to advise her that they can go, but I don't feel inclined to include them on the Census of this Agency, I would therefore like to have a ruling on the matter from the Department at your early convenience. In the meantime I have signed the application for the admission of Arnold, which is attached hereto.

Your obedient servant;

The Secretary;
Indian Affairs Branch.
Ottawa.

(R.M. Moore)

Sir:-

I would respectfully direct your attention to Agnes Thomas, Indian girl of Chemainus Band 16 years last May, and designated as Roll No. 0404 on the Quarterly Report of the Kuper Island School.

This girl is an orphan living with her guardians Marshall Louie and his wife of the Halalt Band. Marshall is quite an old man and is not expected to live many days and it is felt that it would be in the best interests of the girl if she were to return to the School for at least another year or so. However, as she is past the age limit I would like to receive the necessary authority from the Department. So far her discharge has not been asked for.

Dear Sir:

In your letter stating that Norman Elliot and Matilda Harris were legally married and therefore their child Laura would have to be discharged immediately from school, you mention that it is doubtful if the Department would even consider an application on her behalf at this particular time, and regret to inform that you have no alternative but to deplete her name from the Quarterly Returns.

I beg to state however that I acted in good faith when I accepted Norman Elliot's child during the first term. It was difficult for me to know the status of this man, and since there are other Elliots on the Reserves, I thought this one would have the status of an Indian as well.

Had I known that he was a White, I surely would have not accepted his child, certain that I would get no per capita grant for her.

Ottawa, July 10, 1941.

Reverend Sir:

The Department finds it necessary to send back the June quarter return of the Kuper Island Indian Residential School. Due to the manner in which the return has been prepared, the school will lose a considerable amount of grant.

It appears from the information contained in the return that the summer holiday period started about June 15. In that event the school should re-open on August 15.

As you are aware, the Department allows 62 days' holidays with grant each year. Consequently, in preparing the June quarter return, 91 days' grant should have been requested for all pupils who were in residence at the time the holiday period commenced. This would mean that 15 days of the holiday grant would be paid in the June quarter.

In preparing the September quarter return, grant should be asked for each pupil who was in the school at the commencement of the holiday period for the exact number of days they are in residence during the September quarter plus 47 days (62 days holiday grant less 15 days holiday grant already allowed on the June quarter).

Please amend the return accordingly and forward it to the Department.

It is understood, of course, that in the case of pupils in hospital, grant should not be requested

Rev. John Camirand,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Kuper Island, via Chemainus B.C.
for that period. For instance, in the case of pupil No. 443, grant should be requested for only 86 days.

In order to assist you in your financing, a part payment of $2,500 is being forwarded, and the balance will be paid when the amended return is received.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

I have received an Application for Admission to the Kuper Island Residential School, in favour of two children called Percy and Cecelia Thomas who have been living on the Saanich Indian Reserve #2 since the time of birth. In view of certain complications in this matter, I am doubtful about signing the application forms as their Indian Agent.

It would appear that the parents of these children are not married although they have been living together for the past 18 years. Unfortunately however, the mother of the children was legally married 24 years ago to a man called Henry Louis of the Point Grey Indian Reserve and they separated after six years, Henry going to live with another woman of the same Band and she, his legal wife, coming to live with Adam Thomas.

The two children referred to should really belong to the Point Grey Band as they are illegitimate and consequently take the status of the mother. However, as they have been shown on the rolls of this Agency for many years, I would like to be informed if I have the necessary authority to sign the Application for Admission Forms or should send them to Mr. Indian Agent Hall in Vancouver.

Obediently yours,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your above noted letter of the 17th ultimo with reference to the discharge of certain pupils from Residential Schools who might be employed in useful occupations, particularly in the fishing industry, I beg to attach hereto in duplicate a letter received from the Rev. Principal of the Kuper Island Residential School which gives the names of three boys and their particulars whose discharge might be considered for this purpose. My comments on each boy is given below:

Davie Etienne Pierre: The parents of this boy are not engaged in fishing and have not been to my personal knowledge for at least three years. The father works in sawmills and at odd jobs of Longshoring when these are available. If he was to go to his Grandmother at Cowichan Gap it is very doubtful if he would be of any particular use other than to attend to odd jobs around the camp. As he is only 15 yrs. he could not get employment on work outside his own immediate relatives owing to the fact that he has not got a Registration card and can not get one for another year.

Percy Adam Thomas: If this boy was discharged he would simply go with his guardians to the berry fields as that is where they go every summer. The same general conditions apply to this case as the above and in my opinion it would be unwise to allow this boy to go to any fishing camp "on speck" as he would likely be used by the Indians for their own particular benefit, especially as both his parents are dead. The lack of a registration card would also apply in this case.

Sandy Victor Semo: This boy can be of definite use fishing, his parents go fishing every year and are fully equipped. I would recommend the discharge of this boy.

As I understand present regulations, no one is given employment unless he or she is the holder of a National Registration card and such card cannot be issued until the applicant reaches the full age of 16 years, consequently no one under that age can get employment of any kind except with his immediate family;

Indian Agent.

Sir:

re: Roy George, Age 9 years. Cowichan Band. (Quamichan) Pupil of St. Catherine's School shown as No. 12 on report of Sister Mary Eugenia, dated for the term ended May 1942.

I am writing you regarding the above noted boy who I sent to the Kuper Is. Residential school yesterday for the following reasons:

(1) This lad is an orphan being deserted by his mother some five years ago about two years after her husband—the boy's father died—died. The mother left her two children, Roy and his sister Agnes age 8, with their grandmother (who is a widow) and has not come near them since. For the past two years the boy and girl have attended the St. Catherine's school, somewhat irregularly, and during the last two months Roy got completely out of hand and his grandmother was totally unable to control him. She was also having trouble with Agnes and asked me to send them to Kuper Island as she was afraid that they would get into some serious trouble. I agreed to send Roy, but said that if she would keep Agnes for a little longer (in the hope that she might improve) after Roy left it might not be necessary to send the girl to the Residential School for at least a year or so. That is where the matter stands at present and I would ask that the Department be good enough to approve of this arrangement.

I understand that there have been some definite instructions issued regarding the transfer of children from Day to Residential Schools, such transfer not to be made without first reporting the case to the Department and getting the necessary approval. As I do not appear to have received such regulations, I would respectfully request that I be supplied with same.

Yours obediently,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

FORWARDED. It can be seen by Constable Burroughs' report in this connection that SAWYER'S two children are being neglected by their parents. Dear Sir:

I hereby petition the Department for the discharge of Arnold Recalma, a boy who has returned to this school from Coqualeetza hospital last December, and who has been a source of trouble since.

This boy appears to have impulses to do things, which he says he cannot control, and as a consequence becomes a menace to the safety of the school and is the reason why many others are led into mischief.

Prominent among his acts of mischief is his attempt to set fire to a building and taking things from a Post Office located on school grounds. The boy has been duly warned and in response has made what appears to be sincere promises, but to no avail.

As his condition of being convalescent, requires that he follow a special regime calling for rest periods, he has to be about in the school building and finds thus many occasions to indulge his impulses, and it is beyond our convenience to be with him all the time.

Yours very truly,

Rev. J. Cammard.

Kuper Island, B.C.

I beg to submit herewith, in duplicate, a letter received from the Rev. Father J. Camirand, Principal of the Kuper Island Residential School, with reference to Arnold Recalma, recently admitted to the school and approved by the Department under date of February 22nd., file No. 152-0-10.

Up until about a year ago this boy was getting along quite well at this school, then he was discharged and sent to the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital, returning from there about two months ago, and since then he appears to have been a source of annoyance to the Principal and other school officials.

With reference to the attempt to set fire to one of the school buildings and also stealing from the Post Office on the school property, I might say that I instructed the police authorities to investigate and report on both of those offences, copies of which have already gone forward to the Department.

I have received a letter from the Reverend Principal of the Kuper Island School regarding a pupil, Adeline A. Johnny, roll No. 0449, who is sixteen years of age and an orphan. Owing to this girl having reached the maximum school age, I am writing you to request that owing to the circumstances of this girl that she be permitted to remain in the school until she reaches eighteen years of age.

In my opinion it would be most unwise to allow her to return to the reserve because she is the beneficiary of quite a large estate and the first thing we know if this were permitted would be that some of her distant relatives would insist on her marrying some good-for-nothing Indian lad who would most likely exploit the estate to his own advantage.

Dear Sir:

I beg to state I have received your letter of 26th instant, and gather therefrom that the holiday period grant of 62 days covers normally the period extending from July 1st. to September 1st., irrespective of the fact that the pupils leave June 15th, 26th, or any other day in June; and that if part of those 62 days grant is taken in June quarter, that much has to be deducted from the September quarter.

By this I see that I lose out in a great way by wanting to have the pupils leave for the holiday period on June 15th to return on August 15th, so that they may be in school before the general migration to the Hop fields, a reason for absence from school in the beginning of the year. In fact I am out of some five hundred dollars here also, besides the decrease of that much also in the September grant due to a delayed return, as explained in another letter.

By force of this and for a better financial condition, I beg to request that the holiday period be maintained as before, namely July 1st. to September 1st., hoping that with the organization now available, the truant officer or police will be equal to bring about a more timely and regular return of pupils for the opening date.

Yours very truly,

John Camirand

I have your letter of the 6th instant, in further reference to the per capita allowance of the Kuper Island Residential School. A review of your quarterly returns and the correspondence that we have received from you indicates two things:

Dear Mr. Moore:

As you are probably aware, the Department allows grant for 92 days' summer holidays for each pupil at a residential school. Usually schools commence the holiday period on the first of July, which means that all pupils should be returned on the first of September. In the case of those pupils who were in the school on June 30 and allowed home on holidays at that time and returned to the school promptly at the end of the holiday period on September 1, grant is allowed for the September quarter for the full quarter. However, if any pupils do not return on September 1 the school loses grant for the period from the end of the holidays until the date on which the pupils return to the school. In the case of the Kuper Island School, they have been in the habit of taking holidays from June 15 to August 15 and consequently part of the holiday leave is allowed during the June quarter and the balance, or 47 days, is allowed during the September quarter. In other words, for a pupil allowed home on holidays on June 15, who does not return on August 15, the school loses the grant for the period from August 15 to the date of the return of the pupil. I have been in communication with the Reverend Principal of the Kuper Island School with reference to his grant and he seems to be under the impression that, due to our regulations, he is losing grant.

As a matter of fact the reason his grant is not as large as it might be is owing to two conditions:

(a) The enrolment is not sufficiently large;

(b) Some of the children did not return promptly upon the expiry of their leave.

Mr. R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent,
Duncan, B.C.
As an illustration of (a) I might say that the authorized pupilage at the Kuper Island School is 100. We only allow grant for $2.24. In the December quarter, 1942, the average attendance at the Kuper Island School was 72.44, in March, 1943, 85.6, in June 84.65 and in September 74.92. You will consequently see that the grant earned by the school would have been much larger if the attendance for each quarter had been 92.24. Of course, the September average is slightly lower than the others, due to the fact that a number of the children did not return upon the expiry of their leave on August 15. My purpose in writing to you at this time is to bring this matter to your attention with the hope that, if there are any children who should receive institutional care in your agency, you will give the matter your personal attention and arrange to have them placed in the Kuper Island School at the earliest possible date. It is understood, of course, that they would be eligible for admission to that school upon all religious and medical grounds. I should appreciate hearing from you within a month or so regarding your efforts in this particular regard.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

AIR MAIL

Mr. R. H. Moore, Indian Agent, Duncan, B. C.

Re: Children of Pte. Frank A. George

Your letter of the 18th ultimo has been brought to my attention today. I discussed it with Mr. Hoey and we feel that it would be in the best interests of the two children to have them placed in a residential school. I presume, from the third paragraph of your letter, that these children are Catholic, and consequently we believe that immediate arrangements should be made for placing them in the Kuper Island School. You should inform the Principal that the Department will allow supernumerary grant for them, if they are in excess of the number of pupils for whom grant is authorized. In making this decision we feel that we are acting in the best interests of the children, and it is hoped that the Principal of the Kuper Island School will accept them at once.

The usual application forms and certificates of health for these children should be forwarded for our files.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

REPORT ON COWICHAN INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF DECEMBER, 1944

We had about three or four cases of Truancy of pupils from Kuper Is. Res. School, where some of the boys ran away. However, they were all picked up later and returned with the exception of one boy - Norman Jimmie - who was found to be unmanageable and at the request of his parents is being permitted to Attend St. Catherine's Day School on probation. If this course does not prove satisfactory he will be sent to the Industrial School, as he is at present under Court orders for having stolen a bicycle.

Ottawa, July 30th, 1945.

Mr. R.H. Moore, Indian Agent, Duncan, British Columbia,

I am in receipt of the June Quarterly Return of the Kuper Island Residential School. The name of Cecelia Jack No. 0520 was shown on the March return but does not appear on the June Quarterly Return although no application has been received for her discharge. We approved her admission in official letter to you April 17th, 1945. Possibly this girl has left the school but on the other hand the Principal may have neglected to include her name. If she was in school for the June Quarter grant should be requested for that quarter when preparing the September Quarterly Return and a note attached opposite her name giving the file number and date of this letter.

It is noted that pupils No. 546 and No. 0483 were sent to the Sardis Hospital on April 15th. The Principal only requested fifteen days grant. They were entitled to receive forty-five days grant, namely, fifteen days in April and thirty days sick leave grant. In connection with the latter I would refer you to paragraph five of circular letter of December 29th, 1944., a copy of which I enclose. We are allowing forty-five days grants.

In the last paragraph of my letter of April 17th I requested that the dates of entrance should be shown for six pupils.

The corrections have been made with the exception of the date of entrance of pupil No. 2497. This was shown on the June Quarterly Return as August 16th, 1945 and should have read August 15th, 1943. The correct date of entrance for this girl should be shown on future returns.

Dear Mr. Moore:

In answer to your letter of Aug. 6th, I wish to state that the omission of the name of Cecilia Jac., No. 0520 is clearly an oversight on the part of Father Camirand in his last quarterly report. Cecilia still is a pupil at the school; at present she is on her holidays, but she is due to return when school opens again. This is the statement I got from Sister Superior, who is in charge of the girls.

All the other remarks made in Mr. Phelan's letter have been noted and will be acted on in the next report.

The approval of the discharge of pupils No. 556 and No. 0489 is filed.

Yours very truly,

W. Lemmens, S.M.M.
Acting Principal.

Upon the return of Father Camirand, Principal, I shall probably be hearing from him on the matter and will advise you further when I hear from him.

J. Brown

Dear Sir:

I am writing you requesting assistance to get the following children who are at present attending the Songhees Indian Day School to return to the school at which they were previously registered, and which they failed to return to without the necessary permission.

Elsie Jim, Agnes "Kathleen Jim" residing with their father, Joe Jim on the Songhees Band Reserve.

Victor Wilson is also residing with the Joe Jim family and is registered at Kuper Is. Residential school.

Raymond Joe Goldsmith, residing at cabin 17 on the Esquimalt I.R. at the Cannery.

Muriel James, staying with her mother Maggie James on the Songhees I.R. and sometimes goes by the name of Andy Wesley.

Irene Billy, staying with her father Austin Billy on the Songhees I.R.

The easiest way to contact the parents of the aforementioned children would be to interview the children at the Songhees school. Your early attention to this matter will be appreciated and if possible pick up the children and advise the writer who will take them off your hands and see that they are sent to Kuper Is. Residential school.

1. On December 3rd, 1945, the original of the attached copy of letter of the Dept. of Indian Affairs Branch, dated Duncan, B.C., October 29th, 1945, signed by Mr. J.D. Caldwell, Indian Agent, was handed to the writer by the N.C.O. in Charge, Victoria Detachment, instructing that the assignment be undertaken by Cst. L.H.A. Graham, RCMP, and the writer.

2. On December 3rd, 1945, a patrol was made per Police car #2663, from Victoria to the Songhees Indian School, Esquimalt, B.C., where the homes of the Indian children were pointed out by the school teacher.

3. Joe JIM and his wife were interviewed by the writer and informed that Elsie, Agnes and Kathleen JIM also Victor WILSON would have to return, forthwith, to the Kuper Island Residential school with Cst. Graham and the writer. Joe JIM and his wife advised the writer that Victor WILSON was residing with Mrs. ELY on the Quamichian Indian Reserve. Joe JIM and his wife took the instructions in the right spirit and the children stepped into the Police car. Maggie JAMES was subsequently interviewed and Muriel, her daughter, also stepped into the Police car. Patrol then proceeded to cabin 17 on the Esquimalt Indian Reserve in an endeavour to locate Raymond Joe GOLDSMITH. He was not home. It was afterwards learned that he and his sister, Martha JOE, had left in the forenoon and were believed to be en route to the United States for a short visit.

4. Upon making routine enquiries throughout the Songhees and Esquimalt Indian Reserves, it was learned that Irene BILLY was attending St. Catherine's Indian day school at Duncan, B.C.

5. Mr. R. Moore, Indian Agent, Cowichan Indian Agency, Duncan, B.C. was interviewed at Duncan, B.C. and he confirmed the whereabouts of Victor WILSON and Irene BILLY. Mr. Moore stated Victor WILSON and Irene BILLY would be sent over to Kuper Island by his Department.

6. Patrol proceeded to Chemainus, B.C., where Elsie, Agnes and Kathleen JIM together with Muriel JAMES were handed over to Father Camirand to be transported by launch to the Indian Residential school at Kuper Island, B.C.

7. Patrol returned to Victoria in the late p.m. of the 3rd inst.

8. A copy of this report forwarded direct to the Indian Agent, Cowichan Indian Agency, Duncan, B.C. (SGD). Cst. (P.E. Burroughs) #10356.

During a visit to the senior room of the Tsartlip Indian Day School yesterday I received the following information:

"Christopher PAUL, Roll No. 11. of the Tsartlip Band age 51 years, and a widower, who is employed as a fireman at the Patricia Air Fort, has three children attending the Tsartlip schools, Dorothy, 17 years, Philip, 12 years and Anna, 8 years.

It appears that Christopher (or Chris, as he is commonly called) is doing considerable drinking and neglecting his children to the point where he takes them into Victoria about once a week and leaves them in his car while he goes off by himself hunting his favourite bootlegger. The outcome being that Philip, gets tired waiting and he too goes off and occasionally gets drunk himself and stays away for a day or sometimes longer hanging around Chinatown only returning home when he runs out of money or friends. Chris, apparently can do little or anything with this boy—which is to be expected in view of the example he himself sets—and now the lad goes off by himself into town even during the week. All of which adds up to the boy being on the fair road to getting himself into serious trouble.

I also understand that while Chris does nothing to correct the boy, he occasionally gives his daughter Dorothy the occasional beating although she is a good girl and is a very good student at school and anxious to improve her education. It appears that a short time ago the girl went to school with her nose broken and her eyes blackened as the result of a beating from her father, who apparently takes out all his pent-up spite on her.

The Rev. Sister Maureen Regan, Teacher of the school in discussing the matter with me suggested that we take Philip and Anna away from their father and send them to Kuper Is. Res. school, but when the matter was suggested to Chris by the Missionary, he definitely refused to allow them to go.

I am therefore referring the matter to the Department with the recommendation that the Mounted Police be asked to pick up both of these children at their home, without even getting the permission of the father—if necessary, and take them straight up to Kuper Island Res. school and they be made to remain there even during the summer holidays if considered advisable. I know this is more punishment to the children than to the father—who is really responsible—but owing to the fact that the children will not lay a charge against him for neglect there is little that can be done through the Courts without evidence, and even if we did have the evidence, the children should still be sent to the Residential school. I would like to have a reply by Air Mail. Major D.M. MacKay is getting a copy of this letter.

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.

c.c. to Major D.M. MacKay.
Send the following message, subject to the terms on back hereof, which are hereby agreed to:

R. H. Moore, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
DUNGAN,
British Columbia.

YOU ARE AUTHORIZED TO HAVE THE TWO PAUL CHILDREN PLACED
KUPER ISLAND RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

I beg to submit a general report covering the affairs of this Agency for the quarter ending September 30th, 1946.

WELFARE AND TRAINING

All schools in the Agency opened on September 4th and with one or two exceptions the attendance was quite satisfactory and above normal. The principal exception was at Kuper Island Residential School where the Principal seemed slow in getting back some of the pupils that were with their parents at Steveston and in fact on the Reserves. This was brought to their attention several times during the month by me but what the results were during the last week or ten days of September I don't know yet, although up to that time they were disappointing. My own opinion is that the Reverend Principal waits for the children to return rather than taking definite steps himself to bring them back. This has been suggested to him by the writer and also to His Excellency the Bishop of Victoria. It is hoped that we will get better results from now on.

R.H. Moore,  
Indian Agent.

Kuper Island, B.C.

October II/46

Mr. R.H. Moore
Indian Agent
Duncan B.C.

Re: Sammy JACK

Dear Sir:

I have discharged this boy, giving as reason that he is a truant at large, having not to date returned from across the border.

In the event that Sammy should return before the roll is complete, I would request that he be not returned to this school, for the reason that having run away several times, and having done so, in the last instance, after having been given a warning in Juvenile Court, he has caused a great deal of annoyance on this Reserve, having stolen canoes repeatedly to effect his escape.

The Indians also request that he be not permitted to return, because, in addition to having stolen their canoes, this boy has also broken into a home, the last time he ran away, stole a number of valuable things and broke most of all the windows in the house. It was after this that he went to U.S. and has not been back since, from what I hear.

I believe the boy is mentally deficient, and there is little that can be done to correct him; and his presence here would be conducive to more trouble.

Yours very truly,

Rev. J. Camirand

Your File: 152-9-10. (W.T.I.)

Thank you very much indeed for your letter of the 24th inst. instructing me to take Sammy Jack, age 12 years, to the Kamloops Residential School. I think this is an excellent idea and one which should work out very well indeed for the boy.

I should now like to report on a similar case which has to do—this time—with a girl of the Cowichan Band called Agnes Charlie, whose father died about 10 years ago and was deserted by her mother in 1938 when she went to the U.S.A., leaving her two children, aged 5 & 4 years at that time, in the care of their grandmother, Mrs Mary Kate Mechel of the Cowichan Band. This arrangement worked out satisfactorily until about two years ago when we started having trouble with Roy and Agnes about not attending school. Charges of Truancy were laid but owing to the fact that their Grandmother admitted lack of control, they were sent to the Residential school at Kuper Is., but refused to stay there and kept running away. Sometimes weeks elapsed before they could be rounded up and returned, only to again run away. This condition of affairs kept up until last Spring when Roy, aged 13 years then, was charged with tampering with a Railway right of way switch, admitted his guilt and committed to the Boy's Industrial school in Vancouver and where he still is. After this Agnes would attend the local Day School off and on—just enough to make it hard to get anywhere with a charge under the Truancy sections of the Act. However, she was again sent to Kuper Is., but stayed only a matter of two or three weeks and ran away again, taken back again by the R.C.M.P. but ran away again in a matter of hours. She is not going to school now but rather running hither and yon not paying any attention to the warnings given by the writer or to the instructions of her Guardian. As this girl needs discipline and plenty of it, I should like to request that you make the necessary arrangements to have her admitted to the Kamloops Res. school too.

The question of getting her there will not be a problem as I can take Sammy Jack and her up by car at the same time and Mrs Moore can accompany me as Matron. We will be able to get the two children up in one day from Vancouver at much less expense, and with a fraction of the trouble than by train. Kindly reply by Air Mail and immediate action will be taken to take both children there early next month.

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Res File: 152-0-10. (W.T.I).

Re: Leonard James, Kuper Is. Res. School Roll No. 576.

Further to my letter of yesterday's date which was in reply to yours of the 24th. ult. file number mentioned above, I should now like to submit a report on the above noted boy.

This lad of 10 years, is an orphan with very poor home conditions, was admitted to the Kuper Is. Res. school on Jan. 5th. last. He ran away several times and was rounded up and brought back to the school by the Police, the final episode taking place in April when he ran away at the same time as Sammy Jack, as indicated in the June Quarterly report from the school, and eventually got to the U.S. with his mother and older sister where he has remained until a few days ago when he returned to his home reserve. He is not in attendance at any school and on account of poor home conditions he should be at a Res. School, but unfortunately there is no use in sending him to Kuper Is. even if the Principal would accept him as he would just stay there long enough to get clothed properly and then run away again.

May I have your permission to take this lad with me to Kamloops Residential school at the same time that I take his pal, Sammy Jack and Agnes Charlie if you approve of her going there? Kindly advise by Air Mail.

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 5 November 1946.

Mr. R.H. Moore, Indian Agent,
DUNCAN, B.C.

We have your letters of the 31st ultimo and 1st instant with reference to Agnes Charlie and Leonard James. It is presumed from your letters that both these children are in good health and that the only difficulty with them is that they truant when placed in the Kuper Island School.

When authorizing you to place Sammy Jack in the Kamloops School, we thought that this was an exceptional case and that it would not be used as precedent to place other children from your Agency in that school. There is always someone to object when we place children in residential schools situated at a considerable distance from their own home. However, the two children mentioned in the first part of this letter seem to be exceptional cases and we will approve their admission to the Kamloops School providing the Principal is willing to accept them.

We suggest that you communicate with Father O'Grady giving him the facts of the two cases. You might tell him in your letter that we approve of them going to Kamloops but as we are not aware of how many children are enrolled at the present time, we did not feel free to send these two without first consulting him.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Indian Agent,
Duncan, B. C.

Dear Sir:

Virginia Bob, daughter of Modeste Bob of Westholme, of whom I have spoken to you already as having completed her sixteenth year, and being ready to be discharged, but whom you requested to be kept here, as there was a possibility that she would not be properly cared for at home, is causing a great deal of trouble, and a very bad influence for the others in school, inciting many to insubordination.

I have spoken to this girl at three different times for the purpose of having her understand the predicament she would be in, if she was to return home now, and prevailed upon her to behave as she should, but in spite of promises, I see no improvement. She is doing all she can possible do to have herself expelled, all the while being a serious cause of annoyance for everyone.

In view of this I would kindly request that she be discharged and returned to her father, and thus avoid further trouble.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) J. Camirand
Rev. J. Camirand Smm
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
O T T A W A, Ontario.

I beg to attach herewith a copy of a letter received from the Reverend Principal of the Kuper Island Residential School relative to Virginia Bob, number 0477, and which I trust may be found self-explanatory.

For your information I should like to report that I had the father of this girl in the office yesterday and tried to impress on him the importance of keeping a watchful eye on his daughter, Virginia, and which he agreed to do. Taking into consideration all the circumstances connected with this case, I deemed it advisable to allow Virginia to return home yesterday to her father, as there was ample evidence submitted by the father and the Principal to indicate that the School Authorities were unable to handle the girl and I was fearful that she might run away from school and take some of the other children with her. For your information I should like to say that the Kuper Island School seems to have a great deal of trouble lately with the older pupils - boys and girls alike - and I cannot help but feel that the discipline and care of the teachers or supervisors are to blame. Sometimes I feel that the discipline is too strict while at others I am of the opinion that it is not strict enough and at times there is evidence of definite lack of respect on the part of the pupils. This was indicated recently when three or four girls ran away and on being rounded up by the Missionary one of the pupils told the other runaways to slap his face if he tried to make her go back to the school.

Virginia Bob was born on October 17th, 1930 which makes her over 16 years of age now but it was hoped that we might be able to keep her peacefully in school until the end of the current year. In view of the circumstances connected with this case I trust that my actions may be approved in allowing this girl to leave the school without being officially discharged. This letter is going forward in duplicate through the office of the Indian Commissioner.

R. H. Moore,
Indian Agent.

Extract from Report from M.E. Leighton, Agency Nurse, Duncan, B.C., dated July 2nd, 1947.

Saanich I.R. #4

Four children of Sulamina Jack, aged 12, 10, 8 and 5, have been causing a good deal of concern. They are nominally in charge of their grandmother who is at present working on a local berry farm. She leaves the children alone all day and they spend their time wandering the highways for a radius of several miles. The oldest, a boy, David, made friends with a white land, and between them, did a little house-breaking and stealing from the empty houses of David's Reserve - also a store in near-by Sidney. David was taken up to the Kuper Island Residential School but this was far from satisfactory as the School is not organized to care for children during the holiday months. The younger children of this family are still wandering around.

There is a great need for a Home which would give year-round care and guidance to the neglected children of all ages, both school age AND pre-school-age. Good care and discipline during their growing years might reduce the number of irresponsible teenagers who, as at present, are fast giving birth to a new crop of neglected children.
Ottawa, July 19th, 1947.

Mr. R.H. Moore, In Charge,
Indian Agency, Duncan, B.C.

Attached hereto is the September Quarter Return of the Kuper Island Indian Residential School.

In the "Remarks" column you will find notations to the effect that according to our records, you have omitted the names of three pupils who were in residence in June and who are entitled to sixty-two days grant. Please refer to circular letter 150-87 covering the sixty-two days grant for summer holidays.

If on re-checking this Return, you find the above in order, please, include the pupils names in the usual manner and re-submit it for payment.

Meanwhile, we are forwarding a part payment of $3,000.00 to tide you over until full payment can be made.

Philip Phelan,

Please find, attached, copy of a letter received from Rev. Father J. Camirand, relative to an Indian girl who is a pupil at his school. I trust same may be found self-explanatory.

In view of the information given me by the Rev. Principal I authorized immediate discharge of the girl to her Aunt, Mrs. Max Thomas, who has been taking care of her off and on.

I might say that Grace was only admitted to the Kuper Island Residential School last January as she was a problem child at the Saanich Indian Day School and, to try and keep her out of trouble, I had her admitted to the Residential School.

Kuper Island, B. C.

March 22/48

Mr. R. H. Moore
Indian Agent
Duncan B. C.

Dear Sir:

I beg to state that Grace Harry, who was sent here shortly after the Xmas holidays, has proved to be the problem she has been at the East Saanich Day School, in this that she is a very bad influence, not only with the other girls but with the boys as well.

Therefore for the sake of the other pupils who this year have been exceptionally good, I would request that she be discharged immediately. It is to be noted that this girl is sixteen years old.

Yours truly,

"J. Camirand"

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines
OTTAWA.

The discharge from Kuper Island Residential School of pupil No.581 Walter George of Squamish Band, this Agency is requested.

This boy will be 16 years old on May 2nd next. The Rev. Principal advised that he is a very disturbing influence upon the other pupils and apparently he is not amenable to discipline.

As a pupil of this type can be a very disruptive factor in school life I would recommend discharge, especially as he is now almost 16 years old.

His father is dead and his mother has intimated her willingness to take him home and supervise him until he goes to work in early June on a farm.

(H. E. Taylor),
Indian Agent.

Re: Solomon GEORGE - aged 43 years,
Roll No. 15, Quamichan Band.

I am anxious to receive a ruling on the following children of the above noted:

Patricia Delores George -- Born April 17th, 1941
Constance Grace George --- Born September 22nd, 1942.
Lucinda Gloria George ---- Born December 3rd, 1946.

The two oldest children were originally Baptized in the Roman Catholic Church on August 3rd, 1941, and November 7th, 1943, respectively. On April 20th, 1947, both were Baptized into the United Church of Canada and attend the Koksilah Indian Day School. The youngest child was Baptized into the United Church of Canada on April 6, 1947.

Now it turns out that the mother of these girls has developed Tuberculosis and we are anxious to get her into the Nanaimo Indian Hospital. She and her husband are quite agreeable but what to do with the two girls of school age? We would like to send them to a Residential School -- but which one? Catholic or Protestant? The father wants them to go to the latter but, before I make any arrangements, I want to get a ruling from the Department as I know that, years ago, the original Baptism was recognized by Ottawa as the one to go by -- why, I do not know.

As there is considerable urgency in this matter I should like you to please give me an early reply.

R. H. MOORE
Superintendent
Cowichan Agency

Mr. R.H. Moore,

Dear Sir,

Sebastin JACK, child of Cecelia JACK (86) is cause for much worry as he has been breaking in Indian homes, and away most of the time, to the extent that we cannot keep up with him, and there seems to be no way of correcting him as he appears to be mental.

Of late he has been picking up all the matches he can get to, and was found smoking in one of the school rooms. He often goes up to the hay loft in the dead of night, and my worry is that he may set the place a fire.

These last two days he has been hiding in the woods, and feeding most likely on what he has taken from Indian homes. This has been going on most of the time during these holidays, and in view of the fact that the child has no decent home, I felt we would just have to put up with it, but as he is getting to be a menace and the Indians are all much annoyed over it all, I thought I better mention this and see if something could be done.

Yours very truly

(Rev. J. Camirand) smm
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Re: Kuper Island Residential School

Attached is a letter from Mr. Superintendent Moore concerning a request from the Principal of the above-mentioned school for the discharge of a pupil. This letter is being forwarded to the Department for your information and I shall await a report on the medical examination which I have asked Mr. Moore to secure.

This is the last of a number of requests over the last two years which have been received from the Principal in which the mental condition of the pupil has been questioned. The particulars outlined in Father Camirand's letter and also those given in that of Mr. Moore would definitely indicate that the supervision at the school leaves much to be desired.

Inspector Davey has also been concerned about this phase of the operation of the Kuper Island School and has endeavoured to impress upon Father Camirand the necessity of securing a competent staff.

On receipt of the medical report from Mr. Moore I shall communicate with you further.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

W.S. Arneil, Esq. Indian Commissioner for B.C. Vancouver, B.C.

Re: Sebastian Jack. Roll No. 625. Kuper Is. Residential School.

With further reference to your above noted letter and previous communication from Rev. Father Camirand which was sent you attached to mine of the 16th ultimo regarding the marginally noted pupil, I wish to advise as follows:

(1) I asked Dr. J. Goodbrand to visit the school and give me a written report on this boy, particularly his mental condition.

(2) Report received and attached hereto in duplicate.

(3) Application for discharge of the boy received from the Rev. Principal and attached herewith.

(4) An effort is being made by the writer to try and get this lad cared for by a relative at one of the reserves on Discovery Island where he may not have the same opportunity to damage other peoples property. However, this is only a temporary solution for in my opinion if the lad is mentally unbalanced he should not be running at large but committed to the mental hospital in the usual way.

(5) I am not assuming responsibility for such action at the moment, but feel that it might be well to have the lad examined by two doctors, and then action taken, if warranted.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Attached is Voucher No. 10, in favour of myself for cash paid in connection with transportation of Donald Charlie, an Indian boy, to Kuper Island Residential School.

This boy is 13 years old and had been attending St. Mary's School until June last. He was to return in September but when the school was opened he could not be found and his place was filled. He has no mother and his father is shiftless and is at present in jail in the United States. We could not find work for the boy and no one wanted to give him shelter. As Father Camirand had room at his school, he offered to take him.

J. Gillett,
Agency Supt.

OTTAWA ONTARIO.

Re: Sebastian JACK, 12 years,
Roll No.86 Penelakut Band

I examined this boy at Chemainus Hospital on October 10th, 1950, at your request. The reason for examination involved the boy's conduct at Kuper Island Residential School, where he has been mixed up in several episodes. Physically, he is well developed, is well nourished and has a tidy appearance.

The only abnormal physical finding was a heart murmur, which does not impair his routine daily activities. He is alert, makes friends easily -- but immediately breaks into tears when questioned regarding his conduct.

He is in grade III -- which is not advanced enough for a twelve year old boy, but he has been away from school a great part of the time.

He claims he does not like Kuper Island School, but possibly most children would say they did not like school. He definitely denies stealing money in the last episode, where several boys tried to escape from Kuper Island Residential School.

Sebastian's several attempts at escaping and staying in barns overnight, would seem to me to be an endeavour on his part to make himself as big a nuisance as possible so that he would be suspended. However, his grand-mother says this boy would often hide away and they would have to search for him. However, this boy is not an imbecile. He may have a lower I.Q., than average and is easily led by other boys into trouble.

I would recommend that Sebastian be taken from Kuper Island Residential School, to see how he gets along, in a different atmosphere.

Yours very truly,

J. S. GOODBRAND,
Medical Officer.

JSG:LS
Re: Sebastion JACK, Pupil of Kuper Island Indian Residential School.

You will recall the case of the above noted, who was accused by the Reverend Principal of the School mentioned, as being an imbecile.

No evidence was submitted at that time, other than a note from Dr. Goodbrand, stating almost verbatim the sentiments of Father Camirand. These he changed, later.

Recently, this lad and two others ran away from school and spent two days in the bush. They stole some money from the school, before leaving, and later some from an unattended store on Thetis Island. Most of the latter "take" was recovered.

Charges of theft were laid against the boys and they were adjudged to be "Juvenile Delinquents". The parents of the three boys paid back the money to the Store keeper, and two of them were placed in charge of the Principal of the school. Sebastion, was blamed as being the ring leader by the Principal -- although he stated almost immediately, that he was easily led.

This statement by the Principal left little for me to do, except ask the Court to order Sebastion Jack's discharge to the care of his guardian, on condition that he be ordered to report monthly, to the Magistrate. I also suggested that the parents of the three lads be ordered to repay the amount stolen, plus Court Costs. These suggestions were agreed to by the Court, and each parent paid his one third share of the missing funds -- amounting to approximately ten dollars ($10.00), each.

Sebastion is now at home with his grand-parents. I have assigned him to St. Catherine's Indian Day School, and, in all probability, will get along alright. After attending Court, I am more convinced than ever, that poor supervision generally, was the cause.

Enclosed, please find two letters, from Drs. Goodbrand, and Dick, dealing with Sebastion's mental condition.
Until I hear from you or the Department, I have not asked the Principal of St. Catherine's Indian Day School to enroll him. However, I consider that he should attend some school in the interval, if -- for no other reason -- "school discipline".

R. H. MOORE,
Superintendent,
Cowichan Agency.
